ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: The Shelter Island Conferences Revisited: “Fundamental” Physics in the Decade 1975–1985

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The focus of this broad historical overview of “the steady evolution of theoretical ideas” from Shelter Island I in 1947 to Shelter Island II in 1983 is some of the developments in “fundamental” physics after the establishment of the standard model, in particular, the adoption of the view that all present day field theories are “effective field theories” based on the gauge concept; taking seriously big bang cosmology, grand unified field theories (GUTs), and inflation; and the emergence of a new symbiosis of physics and mathematics.

ArticleNote.SimplePara: A condensed version of this essay appeared as the introduction to the reissued Shelter Island II proceedings volume: Roman Jackiw, Nicola N. Khuri, Stephen Weinberg, and Edward Witten, eds., Shelter Island II: Proceedings of the 1983 Shelter Island Conference on Quantum Field Theory and Fundamental Problems of Physics (Mineola, NY: Dover, 2016).

S. S. Schweber is professor of physics and Koret Professor of the History of Ideas, emeritus, at Brandeis University and an associate in the department of the history of science at Harvard University. He is at work on a biography of Hans Bethe.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Together with Sheldon Glashow and Abdus Salam, Steven Weinberg was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1979 for his formulation of the electroweak theory, which unified the quantum field theoretic description of the weak and electromagnetic interactions. He opened his Nobel Prize lecture by stating:
Our job in physics is to see things simply, to understand a great many complicated phenomena in a unified way, in terms of a few simple principles. At times, our efforts are illuminated by a brilliant experiment, such as the 1973 discovery of neutral current neutrino reactions. But even in the dark times between experimental breakthroughs, there always continues a steady evolution of theoretical ideas, leading almost imperceptibly to changes in previous beliefs.1

Weinberg’s remarks highlight insights, often overlooked, regarding the collective aspect of the physicists’ enterprise, and for that matter, of the scientific enterprise more generally. Speaking as an outstanding physicist being recognized for his outstanding contribution to physics, he indicated that he was part of a tightly knit community, that it is “our job in physics,” “our efforts,” and that it is the collective set of beliefs that are imperceptibly changed by the steady evolution of theoretical ideas.2

The foci of this broadly painted historical overview of “the steady evolution of theoretical ideas” from Shelter Island I in 1947 to Shelter Island II in 1983—conferences organized to consider the fundamental problems of physics—are certain aspects of the developments in “fundamental” physics that were made by the high energy physics community after the establishment of the standard model. A related aspect, though here only dealt with impressionistically, is the changing character and role of the collective by virtue of the increase in the size of the community, the competence of the practitioners, and their specialization.3 During the period under consideration, the tempo of production of new knowledge changed dramatically and the level of the competence of the practitioners increased greatly. Hence, the role of the collective changed, as did the nature of the individuals who contributed importantly and generatively to the advances in knowledge.

The standard model is the quantum field theoretical description of the interactions between quarks, gluons, leptons, and Higgs bosons. It combines electroweak theory—the quantum field theoretic description of the weak and electromagnetic interactions—with quantum chromodynamics (QCD)—the field theoretic description of the strong interactions. Both electroweak theory and QCD are gauge theories, a special class of quantum field theories in which an invariance principle uniquely specifies the form of the interactions which are necessarily mediated by gauge bosons. Understanding gauge theories led Chen-Ning Yang (who, with Robert Mills, was responsible for introducing non-abelian gauge theories into physics) to formulate the principle that “symmetry dictates interactions” which he considered as “one part of Einstein’s geometrization of physics.”4 QCD explains how unobservable quarks can combine and give rise to observable mesons and nucleons (the hadrons),5 which in turn can combine to give rise to stable nuclei, which when binding with electrons give rise to the observed atoms and molecules whose structure and properties are described by quantum electrodynamics (QED).6

The basic working assumption of the standard model is that there are two “foundational” sets of building blocks of matter:
(1)
A fermion component consisting of:
a.
six spin ½ quarks (up, down; charm, strange; top, bottom) expressing the “flavor” degrees of freedom of the quark. Each quark also carries an additional degree of freedom expressed by its three “colors”;
b.
six spin ½ leptons, (ν e , e
− ; ν μ , μ; ν τ , τ), which only carry a flavor degree of freedom, identical with that of the quarks.

The quarks and the leptons all are spin ½ entities, and can be fit into three “generations” composed of (u, d, e, νe), (c, s, μ, ν μ ) and (t, b, τ, ν τ ).7
(2)
A bosonic component consisting of spin 1 entities:
a.
the photon, the W ±, and the Z, responsible for the electroweak forces between quarks and leptons; and
b.
eight color gluons that carry color degrees of freedom and mediate the strong forces between quarks. They also interact strongly with one another.
(3)
A bosonic component consisting of spin 0 Higgs bosons that are responsible for giving masses to the W ± and the Z,8 to the quarks, and to the leptons.9

The electroweak interactions are described by a gauge theory based on an SU(2) × U(1) symmetry that involves only the flavor degrees of freedom.10 The strong interactions are described by a gauge theory based on an SU(3) color degrees of freedom. The quarks are involved in both sets of interactions, with each factor, SU(3), SU(2), U(1), having a single, independent gauge coupling constant.

The particularly attractive feature of the standard model is that all the fields are gauge theories.11 Once the gauge group and representations are specified, the gauge interactions are uniquely determined with one coupling constant determining the strength of the interactions for the given group factor. Even though the gauge invariance seemingly requires the gauge bosons to be massless, which would result in long-range forces, the non-abelian character of the SU(3) color group, which manifests itself in interactions between the color charge carrying gluons, the QCD interactions are in fact short range. Strong coupling effects at large distance scales prevent the colored quarks and gluons from propagating as free particles. The weak interactions are also short range because the associated gauge bosons acquire masses by the introduction of a Higgs scalar field that spontaneously breaks the gauge symmetry of the vacuum of the theory. The existence of the scalar Higgs boson was established in 2012. Indeed, the Higgs boson is the only scalar “elementary” particle known to date and introduces a new “force” between the quarks and the bosons responsible for the electroweak and strong forces.12

The standard model, as expressed in the language of quantum field theory (QFT), is one of the most remarkable physical theories yet devised and one of the greatest accomplishments of the human species. The range of its applicability—from the sub-nuclear to the cosmological, some twenty orders of magnitude—is staggering. But the standard model’s twenty or so parameters (which specify the masses of the quarks, of various bosons, of coupling constants, all related to the Higgs boson and the mechanisms for generating masses of the leptons, quarks and the weak bosons),13 the fact that it treats the electroweak and strong forces separately, and its inability to incorporate general relativity indicate its limitations.14 New concepts of objects, interactions, space and time, and geometry, for example, will have to be considered and introduced.15 It is widely believed that relativistic quantum field theory—the foundational mathematical language used so far in the quantum description of nature, which attributes a pointlike character to the quarks, gluons, leptons and to their interactions with one another and with the Higgs bosons—is an “adequate” mathematical language in the domain in which the standard model is applicable but may have reached the limits of its validity.16 String theory, which is a generalization of quantum field theories in which the “foundational” elementary entities are not described as pointlike objects but as different modes of excitation of a string-like extended entity, has the valuable features that, on the one hand, it incorporates gravitation in an essential manner and, on the other, that by virtue of dealing with extended objects it does not encounter the divergences of relativistic quantum field theory. It remains to be seen whether string theory can yield observational or experimental, falsifiable, consequences.17

Establishing the validity of the standard model was a collective enterprise of the high energy physics community. On the theoretical side, one can point to certain individuals whose contributions stand out. In endnote 18, I have given a small list of such people,18 a list somewhat arbitrarily chosen, which reflects the need to limit the size of the endnote. Many more individuals who made important and generative contributions could be added to that list, especially individuals who entered the field in the late 1960s. Whom to include under what heading is also somewhat arbitrary. The boundaries between theoretical high energy physics, condensed matter physics, mathematical physics, computational physics, mathematics, etc., were and are porous and the frequency of their being crossed is indicative of the unusual abilities of the practitioners. Their competence reflects the demands and standards in the field. These standards are implemented by the demands that outstanding textbooks be mastered during the education of theorists. The importance attached to textbooks is indicated by the status of those who write the graduate level textbooks.19 The competence also reflect the importance of the summer schools in theoretical physics in the education of theorists—les Houches, Brandeis, Boulder, Cargèse, Erice, Varenna, and others20—and the value of the quick availability of the lectures given at them by the leading experts and innovators responsible for the advances, lectures that presented critical reviews of recent developments.

Some of the theorists listed in endnote 18 were rewarded by Nobel Prizes—but it should be remembered that there is always an element of contingency, of politics, and of implementation of power in its selections.21 The high energy community was and is populated by remarkable individuals, many of them “off-scale.” For a host of reasons, some scientists whose cultural impact has been extraordinary—for example, Newton, Einstein, and Maxwell—became seen as exceptional and matchless and were mythologized. I believe that some of the mentioned theorists in endnote 18 were—are—as “off-scale” as Einstein, Maxwell, or Newton as far as their intellectual production is concerned. This is not to make Einstein, Maxwell, or Newton less “off-scale.” Indeed, theirs are some of the greatest achievements of the human mind. Nor do I wish to deny the extraordinary influence and impact an individual can make. But note that that there were only a handful of natural philosophers in Newton’s time; that physics became a separate discipline only in Maxwell’s time,22 with as yet no specialization between experimental and theoretical physics; and that there were only a few dozens outstanding theoretical and mathematical physicists during the first two decades of the twentieth century when Einstein made his exceptional contributions.23 This contrasts with the several hundred outstanding theorists addressing problems in high energy physics in the period between Shelter Island I and Shelter Island II. Even more important was the plethora of new accelerators of ever-higher energies coming into operation after Shelter Island I, the ever growing, ever more precise and robust sets of data being generated by them that became critical for formulating new models and theories. The thus generated numbers became evidence for a particular model or theory, or the basis for refuting a particular model or theory. These numbers had implications more extensive and wide ranging than those Einstein dealt with to corroborate his general theory of relativity. In addition, the tempo of the generation and of the evolution of theoretical ideas dramatically accelerated with the steady increase of the size of the high energy community. Similarly, the tempo at which the collective set of beliefs changed accelerated by virtue of the steady production of robust, precise, new data and the growth of the size of the community.

Every theorist who contributed to the establishment of the standard model drew on the extensive, cumulative, collective knowledge of the community. The new knowledge they produced was critically analyzed by the community, and the acceptance by the community of their findings reflected a collective consensus and asserted the validity of their efforts.

To emphasize the role of the social dimension of the collective and point to the bias cultural factors have introduced, I will here only note the importance of what Robert Merton has called the Matthew effect,24 namely, that the rich in fame and status get richer and the poor poorer. It is not merely that an eminent scientist will often receive more credit than a not-as-well recognized colleague for similar work they both did independently or that credit will usually be given to researchers who are already famous. The eminent scientist will usually be at a “richer” and “higher status” institution, hence have more outstanding colleagues, have more outstanding postdoctoral students working with him or her, be exposed to more seminars and colloquia devoted to recent advances, and therefore have more interactions with active researchers working at the frontiers of the field than workers at “poorer” or somewhat lower-status institutions.25 They thus have the possibility (and the ability) to work out quickly and successfully latent generative ideas they may have heard of. The net effect of all this is that his or her status is not just maintained by being at such an institution but that the potentiality of it being enhanced is always there.26 The converse is also true: those not in such positions, or at such institutions are somewhat disadvantaged. The introduction of arXiving one’s papers has greatly democratized the process, but often when a paper is made accessible on arXiv, its senior author is already extending the work.

There are additional elements at work in the Matthew effect, factors whose importance has increased by virtue of the increasing size of the scientific communities and the accelerating tempo at which scientific knowledge is produced. The “rich” can now get richer and reap preferential credit by virtue of being invited as speakers or commentators to the ever more numerous workshops and conferences being held. But they also get “richer” by virtue of the power they hold and are able to exert, power that affects an ever-greater number of people. This by virtue of having an important voice on the committees that allocate research grants, by virtue of being able to place their students in positions at leading universities, by virtue of having influential editorial voices at periodicals having high impact factors—all this, in addition to the respect and esteem they command by virtue of their scholarly achievements.

High energy physics, mathematical physics, condensed matter physics, and other subfields must be seen as constituting special kinds of communities of practice,27 operating in specific contexts, so that in order to understand their evolution attention must also be paid to the social interaction dimension within these communities and their institutions. To substantiate the role of the collective and to exhibit the dynamics involved in the creation and acceptance of new knowledge would require a fine-grained analysis of the social structure of the closely knit high energy theoretical physics community and of its cooperative and collaborative interactions that take place in a fiercely competitive environment.28 It would have to consider the administrative and intellectual leadership of the various communities of practice into which high energy theoretical physics has split and how high energy theorists are molded by the various hoops they are made to jump through: as undergraduates to obtain their bachelor degrees; as graduate students taking the required courses; as members of their thesis supervisors “families” of pre-docs and postdocs; as postdocs to demonstrate their originality and productivity.29 And it would necessitate an extensive analysis of the wider context in which the community evolved and therefore a consideration of the restructuring of universities and physics departments after World War II; an analysis of the role played by preprints; by the summer schools in theoretical physics and the lectures given there by outstanding contributors, lectures that introduced and assessed the most recent developments to large numbers of graduate students and postdocs in a setting that made for strong, informal interactions between lecturers and students; an analysis of the role played by the ever greater number of conferences—and of course, the political and economic factors that made all this possible: World War II, nuclear weaponry, the Cold War, the Picketty bubble between 1945 and 1970,30 the structure of the political institutions during that period, etc.31 It thus would require a much more extensive presentation than is possible in this exposition, and much more reflection before attempting to do so.

Within the compass of this paper, I will only give a very broad overview of the context in which the collective sets of beliefs developed between Shelter Island I and Shelter Island II, and this with a minimum of technical details.

There are several critical observations to be made regarding high energy experimental physics at the two endpoints. Progress in physics has always been determined by the strong coupling and interactions between theory, experiment, and instrumentation. More precisely, advances stem from the interaction among theory/theorists, experimenters and the data generated by them by observations and experiments, and the instruments used therein. The latter in turn are strongly coupled to technological developments.32 Of course, advances also reflect the context in which they were produced. In experimental high energy physics, the period from 1947 until the late 1970s was marked by the construction of ever more energetic accelerators and colliders, culminating in the late 1970s with DESY’s Petra, Fermilab’s Tevatron, and CERN’s Super Proton Synchrotron, accelerators achieving energies in the several hundred GeV range. When Shelter Island II took place, experiments on these machines had established the central components of the standard model.33 No new “startling” data were expected from the existing accelerators, only more precise data yielding further verifications of the standard model, and with the increasing precision perhaps the production of some data indicating possible discrepancies. That no new data at much higher energies would be forthcoming for probably a decade is one of the contextual factors that helps us understand the state of high energy physics in the early 1980s and helps us interpret the presentations at Shelter Island II.

Partly due to the corroboration of the standard model (except for the Higgs sector); partly due to the fact that no new accelerator or collider was operating; partly due to the general curtailment of government funding after the Vietnam war; partly due to neoliberalism becoming a dominant voice in shaping governmental and corporate policies; partly because of important advances in molecular biology—and their translation into pharmaceuticals—that made biology the premier scientific field and attracted outstanding students; because of all these occurrences high energy physics in the United States was undergoing a transition in the early 1980s.

Drastic changes had occurred in the way experimental high energy physics was being done. Christine Sutton34 gave a readily accessible, insightful, contemporaneous account of the transformation in her description of the enormous Underground Area (UA) detectors at CERN, their associated technologies, the huge manpower connected with their operation, and the interpretation of the enormous amount of data generated by them.35 The conventional wisdom at the time was that high energy physics was headed for an era of even larger collaborative experimental groups working at an ever smaller number of accelerators and interaction regions. This inference was being referred to colloquially as “fewer spigots and bigger detectors.”36 Complementing this assessment were worrisome trends in the availability, training, and size of the manpower pool: the number of graduate students in experimental high energy physics had drastically decreased during the 1960s, only bottoming out in 1973. In the early 1980s, only about 125 PhDs in experimental high energy physics were being awarded in the US annually, as compared to 250 at the peak. Furthermore, the numbers were dropping again and the average length of time to obtain a PhD had increased to six years.37 Adding to the manpower problem, during the 1970s, about half of the experimental physicists who had obtained (temporary) postdoctoral positions after obtaining their PhDs left the field after two years.

This worrisome state of affairs was underscored in the proceedings of the 1982 Snowmass “Summer Study of Elementary Particle Physics and Future Facilities” that the Division of Particles and Fields of the American Physical Society organized.38 The purpose of the three weeks meeting was “to assess the future of elementary particle physics, to explore the limits of our technological facilities, and to consider the nature of future major facilities for particle physics in the United States.”39 Snowmass 1982 represented a restructuring of the practice of particle physics in the United States and was the result of a dedicated effort to have the national community involved the planning of the American high energy program. Past studies had typically been organized by one of the large laboratories (such as Fermi, SLAC, Brookhaven, or Cornell) to consider issues and problems specific to that particular laboratory. In contrast, Snowmass 1982 brought together high energy physicists from the entire US “to consider the future of the field from the point of view of the best national program.” Attendance at the meeting was open to everyone active in particle physics in the US. Some 150 persons participated in the study, two-thirds holding positions at universities, and one-third working at the national laboratories. Also in attendance were representatives from European high energy laboratories, and the problems addressed were not limited to those in the US.

That experimental tools in high energy physics had become monstrously big and experiments were becoming extraordinarily slow was reflected in the composition of the theorists attending Shelter Island II. The transformation had split the high energy theory community. One component was composed of the theorists whose work was closely tied to experiments and the analysis of data generated by accelerators, theorists who were concerned with what experiments might be devised on the next generation of accelerators; another comprised the theorists involved in the design of the next generation of accelerators, storage rings, and colliders. Still another component was made up of the theorists who had become committed to one or another aspect of supersymmetry or of the early developments of string theory. Another component consisted of theorists who were leaving high energy physics because they were beginning to work in other disciplines. For Freeman Dyson (Fig. 1) particle physics had become “boring” because each experiment took a decade or longer to do. For him, the exciting frontier of physics had moved from particles to astronomy. After 1983, Dyson “stopped talking” to particle physicists and talked instead to astronomers and biologists.40 In fact, as Shelter Island II indicates, quite a number of young particle physicists had become cosmologists. Others, like Larry Abbott, an outstanding young particle physicist who had become a cosmologist in the late 1970s, turned his attention to the neurosciences in the mid-1980s.41

Snowmass 1982 revealed some of the deep structural changes in the practice of experimental high energy physics. Similar deep changes occurred in theoretical physics during the 1970s with consequential changes in the practice of theoretical physics. Shelter Island II made these changes evident and explicit.

In high energy physics, the establishment of the standard model as the foundational quantum theory gave quantum field theories based on the gauge principle a special status as the mathematical language in which to formulate theories and recognized gauge theories as manifesting a deep phenomenological symmetry of nature. But concurrently it became recognized that the regularization and renormalization procedures that were applied in order to extract observable consequences from all relativistic quantum field theories needed to be reinterpreted. This resulted in reconceptualizing all of the foundational field theories—Glashow-Weinberg-Salam (GWS) electroweak theory, QCD, general relativity—as “effective field theories” of limited range, not considered as “fundamental” theories.

I emphasize this difference between “foundational” and “fundamental.” The quantum theory formulated in terms of quantum field theories had hierarchized the physical world. The atomic, nuclear, and subnuclear domains each have a set of “elementary” entities that populate that domain and each has a “foundational” theory, an effective field theory, which governs the dynamics of these entities.42

The notion of a foundational theory is further elucidated by recalling Ian Hacking’s characterization of laboratory sciences as engaged in the creation of phenomena, and more precisely, in the purification and maintenance of phenomena “that do not exist in a pure state anywhere in the universe.”43 Foundational theories refer to these phenomena, phenomena that can be “maintained in the laboratory, brought back when interesting, or transformed into off-the-shelf transportable technology.” Furthermore, Hacking indicated that “this notion of purifying, creating and regularizing phenomena (and hence the world that we inhabit) certainly involves thinking and theorizing about the material world, but it also involves interaction with the world, and, in an unmetaphorical sense of the words, remaking it.” Hacking went on to state:
The world with which we interact does not fix just what discoveries or inventions shall be made, nor does our past knowledge determine what we shall count as a discovery. It is not preordained which instruments we shall devise, nor which phenomena we shall be able to stabilize or purify. A science can develop among many possible paths, bringing into being different phenomena. Phenomena that we create on one possible historical path might not be created on another historical path, say because we have invented neither the instruments nor the theory of the instruments through which we could recognize or control them. Moreover any path that we do follow has its own momentum. Experimental techniques and instruments, when they produce what are taken to be stable results, themselves suggest further steps to take by analogy. Had we not started out on a path, we would not have created later on what we do in fact create.44

Foundational theories provide the dynamics responsible for the phenomena experimenters have been able to stabilize or purify. Moreover, the path taken with the adoption of the quantum theory of particles and of fields, a path which hierarchizes nature into delineated domains with phenomena therein rendered stable in Hacking’s sense, has up to this point proven generative. In fact, the path taken has self-stabilized itself.45

In his talk in July 2009 at the Sixth International Workshop on Chiral Dynamics, Steven Weinberg reviewed the development of effective field theories (EFT) of strong interactions. In his opening remarks he noted that “it all started with current algebra” and indicated that until the mid-1970s effective field theories were considered only as a tool to derive results from current algebra more easily.46 They were not considered dynamical theories, because they contained derivative couplings that made them useful in the lowest order of perturbation theory, but which in turn made them nonrenormalizable. Weinberg’s assessment of EFTs changed in 1976 when he gave a series of lectures on the theory of phase transitions at the Erice summer school and had studied Kenneth Wilson’s approach to integrating out short-distance degrees of freedom by introducing a variable ultraviolet cutoff.47 In Wilson’s approach, the bare couplings are given a cutoff dependence that guarantees that physical quantities are cutoff independent. But with the introduction of the cutoff it becomes necessary to introduce every possible interaction in the effective field theory in order to mimic the integrated-out contributions locally and to keep the physics cutoff independent, this even if the underlying theory is renormalizable.48 With the cutoff, non-renormalizable theories are just as renormalizable as renormalizable theories. Effective field theories derived by integrating out heavy particles were investigated by Thomas Appelquist and James Carrazone.49

An illustration of this approach is the following. The foundational theory of weak interactions is the renormalizable GSW electroweak theory in which the weak interactions are mediated by the exchange of vector bosons that acquire their mass from a symmetry-breaking mechanism involving scalar Higgs bosons. When all the fermion energies are much lower than the intermediate boson masses, the low energy Fermi quark theory of weak interactions describes the weak interactions by an effective action with a current-current interaction term, where the current gets a contribution from both the quarks and the leptons.50

This effective field theory can be recovered from the GWS electroweak theory by “integrating out” the bosons. In the language of functional integration,

Upon carrying out the integration, the Fermi constant becomes related to the parameters in the GWS theory. The current-current Fermi theory with quarks as the “foundational” entities can thus be considered as an effective long wavelength quantum field theory (for wave lengths longer than 10−16 cm, or equivalently for energies below 100 GeV). Its region of validity is given by the mass of the top boson.

Incidentally, this example also points to the ever-greater adoption of Richard Feynman’s path integral formulation of quantum mechanics. The extension and application of Feynman’s path integral to gauged quantum field theory by Ludvig Faddeev and Victor Poppov in 1967 was a crucial calculation.51 Pierre Ramond’s widely used and taught Field Theory: A Modern Primer,52 which presents quantum field theory in terms of Feynman path integrals with the intent of using this approach in carrying out research, gives proof of the path integral’s usefulness and importance.

EFTs opened the door to applying quantum field theory to gravitation even though there is no renormalizable theory of the metric tensor that is invariant under general coordinate transformations. Thus, at Shelter Island II, Steven Adler presented arguments that the Einstein-Hilbert Lagrangian should be considered the least suppressed term in the Lagrangian of an effective field theory53 containing every possible generally covariant function of the metric R and its derivatives.54

Weinberg, in his 2009 lecture, stressed an important limitation regarding classical general relativity: “One consequence of viewing the Einstein–Hilbert Lagrangian as one term in an effective field theory is that any theorem based on conventional general relativity, which declares that under certain initial conditions future singularities are inevitable, must be reinterpreted to mean that under these conditions higher terms in the effective action become important.”55

It has been argued that the validity of the effective field theory approach depends on the unproven assumption of the existence of a “final theory.”56 But a less all-encompassing basis for the approach is appealing to the historical developments. One can consider the non-relativistic Schrödinger equation as derived from a non-relativistic quantum field theory, in which the mass and charge of the electron and those of the nuclei are empirically determined parameters. Subsequent developments—QED, electroweak theory, QCD—reduced dramatically the number of parameters to some twenty or so and allowed a partial reconstruction of the physical world in very special environments, that is, gave an explanation of the existence of entities such as mesons, neutrons, and protons. This reduction in the number of parameters and the experimental corroboration of the standard model then supplies the validation for the EFT approach: it is hugely generative. The parameters in the standard model reflect our ignorance of the physics at distances smaller than that specified by the largest mass at which the EFT is a valid representation of the dynamics.

I conclude this subsection on effective field theories with Yuri Manin’s observation: “The image of Plato’s cave seems to me the best metaphor for the structure of scientific knowledge; we actually only see the shadows.”57

Another striking development of the mid-1970s was, in cosmology, the establishment of its “standard model”: the Robertson-Walker model that describes—when averaged over large distances—the present-day homogeneous and isotropic distribution of matter and energy in the universe.58 The discovery in 1965 of the 3 K background microwave cosmic radiation (BCR) by A. A. Penzias and R. W. Wilson resulted in the general acceptance in the West of a hot big bang as the beginning of the universe.59 In its idealized version, the hot big bang theory asserts that the universe was born at some definite moment about some 13.8 billion years ago in a state of infinitely high temperature and infinitely large density. By the mid-1970s, there was a consensus in the West that there had been a big bang and that subsequently the universe had evolved from a state of extreme simplicity into a state of astounding complexity. The question became: “What are the dynamics that make it possible for the early universe to be so remarkably simple as indicated by the BCR and for it to be at present essentially homogeneous and isotropic (as far as matter and energy are concerned)?” Concomitantly, another question was: “How did the complex galactic structure that we observe today come to be?”

The advances in particle physics that occurred in the 1970s provided some of the answers. The standard model greatly extended the range of energies—hence temperatures—and densities over which theoretical predictions could be made. It was this that allowed the exploration of the history of the universe at much earlier times.

In fact, in the mid-1970s, high energy physics and cosmology became amalgamated.60 The symbiosis and its evolution transformed the natural sciences. In the final version of his opening lecture at Shelter Island II, Murray Gell-Mann observed “particle physics and cosmology…[have] essentially merge[d] into one field, the field of fundamental physics which underlies all of natural science.”61 In high energy physics, the fundamental question addressed by the community became: “How did the standard model come to be?” In fact, the data for the possible empirical corroboration of a possible more “foundational” theory—whether a grand unified theory or one incorporating supersymmetry—began coming not only from SLAC, DESY, Fermilab, and CERN and their huge accelerators and detectors, or from Kamiokande and its huge water tank and thousands of photodetectors, but also, and ever more frequently, from astrophysical and cosmological data, such as the data obtained from the Hubble space telescope, the COBE satellite, and the LIGO gravitational wave detector.

The acceptance of big bang cosmology transformed nuclear physics into nuclear science, a subdiscipline that encompasses all aspects of the genesis of matter since the time after the big bang when the standard model becomes a fairly accurate, precise, and robust description of the foundational entities that make up matter.62 Similar issues are addressed in the planetary sciences,63 where investigations try to give answers to questions such as: “How did all the chemical compounds that arise in the formation of planets come to be?,”64 “How did the moon come to be?,”65 “What makes a planet habitable to forms of life?,”66 “What makes the cosmos fit for life?”67 In that general sense, the natural sciences have become evolutionary sciences, animated by a Peirceian Weltanschauung that stipulates: “Don’t tell me what the law is. That closes the door to understanding. Tell me how it came to be.”68

The merging of elementary particle physics and cosmology was also responsible for taking seriously inflationary models of the universe after the hot big bang. Shelter Island II highlights this development by the prominence given to the lectures of Alan Guth and Andrei Linde. All the various inflationary models assume the existence of a stage in the evolution of the very early universe after the big bang during which it expands exponentially. This exponential expansion is referred to as inflation.

The idea of inflation arose from the applications of new insights in particle physics, in particular from grand unified theories (GUT), to cosmology. Inflation constitutes an attempt to give an answer to why the early universe could be remarkably simple yet evolve to its present state of being, on the very large scale, essentially homogeneous and isotropic. Inflation also gives plausible answers to other foundational cosmological questions.69

Inflation revolutionized cosmology because it eliminated the dependence of modeling on initial conditions. In hot big bang cosmology there is a time, essentially set by the Planck scale,70 before which one cannot say anything because the dynamics that hold prior to that time is unknown. Pre–big bang cosmologies depended critically on the state of the universe at the Planck time. Very unnatural initial conditions had to be imposed for the universe to end up isotropic and homogeneous. Furthermore, all galactic structure had to be included as part of the initial data in the form of small perturbations.71 These did not did not arise spontaneously as a result of quantum fluctuations, as in inflationary models.

The possible existence of an inflationary mechanism had been considered by Gliner, Linde, and Starobinski in the 1970s.72 It was Alan Guth who formulated an inflationary model that made inflation plausible. His model simultaneously solved, first, the problem of monopoles—the extremely heavy particles carrying magnetic charge that would, according to many GUTs, be created in the very hot, very early universe and would be abundant at present73; second, the flatness problem, namely that one would expect the universe to display a large curvature reflecting the fact that the only natural length parameter in a quantum gravity theory is the Planck scale, whereas the geometry of the universe seems to be Euclidean on the scale of the radius of the observable universe; and third, the horizon problem, which can be stated as the following question: “Why did all the causally disconnected regions of our present day universe start their expansion simultaneously?”

But Guth’s model suffered from the fact that after inflation the universe would be too inhomogeneous. In 1982, Linde, and independently Albrecht and Steinhardt,74 suggested a new inflationary model. But also their model had severe deficiencies. In 1983, at Shelter Island II, Linde proposed his chaotic inflationary model, which alleviated these problems. By the time of Shelter Island II, it had become clear that an inflationary cosmology could arise from a wide range of initial conditions and that a central problem was to explain the fluctuations observed in the spectrum of the cosmic black body radiation as these were closely connected with galaxy formation.

Another major confluence of developments took place in the 1970s, which resulted in a new, cooperative, amazingly generative, symbiotic relationship between physics and mathematics. Thus Dyson in his 1983 review of Manin’s Mathematics and Physics could state: “In Manin’s view, the present epoch is characterized by a growing willingness of physicists and mathematicians to learn from each other and to transfer tools and techniques from one branch to another. The increasing overlap between physics and mathematics provides opportunities for the continued enrichment of both disciplines.”75 There were many reasons for how this came about. The early research on quantum field theories was concerned with aspects that could be addressed using perturbation theory, such as proofs of the renormalizability of such theories. However, it turns out that it is possible for quantum field theories to violate a symmetry that is present at the classical level, i.e., in the limit when h→0.76 When this occurs, one speaks of the theory having an anomaly. Mathematically, violating a symmetry means that it is impossible to construct a unitary representation of the symmetry transformations of the classical system underlying the quantum description on the Hilbert space of state vectors of the quantum theory. If it is impossible to construct such a representation that commutes with the Hamiltonian of the quantum theory, one then characterizes the situation as a violation of a dynamical symmetry.77 It turns out that understanding anomalies can be viewed as a problem in algebraic topology.78 Furthermore, non-abelian gauge theories, such as the SU(3)-based Yang-Mills field theories are highly non-linear and have non-perturbative solutions that already at the classical level, have deep, unsuspected properties—e.g. instantons, solutions of the classical Euclideanized Yang-Mills equations of motion that are localized in all directions of space-time, solutions that depend on the dimension of the space-time.79 Understanding these aspects of non-abelian gauge theories likewise required understanding the topological properties of gauge field theories and their dependence on spatial dimension.

The early research on non-abelian gauge quantum field theories was concerned with proofs of the renormalizability of such theories when the symmetry of theory was spontaneously broken; with investigations of their short distance behavior; with calculations that validated asymptotic freedom and certain others features of the theory. All these problems could be addressed, and dependable results obtained, by using perturbation theory. Even so, the problem of quark confinement required a non-perturbative approach to gauge theories and led to the introduction of tools from differential geometry and algebraic topology.80 As ’t Hooft observed: “Without understanding the physics, mathematics does not answer your questions. Without understanding the mathematics, your physics theories will not work successfully either.”81 The importance of mastering these mathematical aspects of gauge quantum field theories is indicated by the fact that the 1979 Cargèse Summer School was devoted to these recent developments in gauge theories and that three leading mathematicians who had been responsible for important mathematical advances of great relevance for the deeper understanding of non-abelian gauge theories—Michael Atiyah, Raoul Bott, and Isadore Singer—were invited to give lectures at the school.82 The organizers of the summer school in the preface to the published lectures commented: “The presence of mathematicians as enthusiastic participants and masterful lecturers in this school deserves special mention. We hope this trend will continue.”83

What was new about this new interaction between physics and mathematics was that physicists were attacking problems in “pure” mathematics and, conversely, mathematicians were attacking problems in “pure” physics, in quantum field theory and string theory. Traditionally, physics had provided mathematical problems and mathematicians provided or had provided the solutions to these problems (such as Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, Leonhard Euler, Joseph-Louis Lagrange, Carl Friedrich Gauss, Bernhard Riemann, Gregorio Ricci-Curbastro, Tullio Levi-Civita, David Hilbert, Emmy Noether, Hermann Weyl, and John von Neumann).84 The relationship at times resulted in the development of new mathematics (Fourier series, Weiner-Feynman-Kac integrals, Murray–von Neumann operator algebras, etc.). What was dramatically new since the mid-1970s was that physicists were formulating stunning conjectures that subsequently mathematicians were able to frame and express as rigorous mathematical statements, and in the process a great deal of new mathematics was being created. The symbiosis has proven to be amazingly generative for both physics and mathematics.

An example of this new symbiotic relation between physics and mathematics is the following: In 1982, making use of the nonlinear space of instanton parameters as a new geometrical tool, Simon Donaldson (as a second year graduate student!), proved a result that, according to the eminent mathematician Michael Atiyah, “stunned the mathematical world.” Donaldson’s findings implied that there exist “exotic” four-dimensional manifolds that are topologically but not differentially equivalent to the standard Euclidean four-space. In the hands of Edward Witten, Joseph Polchinski, Nathan Seiberg, and others, supersymmetric field theories and string theories turned out to be amazingly powerful and generative tools for the development of new results in algebraic and differential topology and other mathematical fields.85 Witten was awarded the Fields Medal 1990 for his contributions to mathematics.86

It is interesting to note that these advances, both in physics and in mathematics, stemmed from attempts either to unify, or from a recognition of a unity in what appeared to be disparate components (and subdisciplines) of either physics or mathematics. In both mathematics and in physics, a belief in unification has played an essential role.87 It is easier to specify the nature of the unification sought in physics, where the attempt to encompass the strong, the electroweak and gravitational forces in a single theoretical framework is the driving motivation and where “nature” provides standards for adequacy.88 I am not competent even to adumbrate what would constitute a “unification” of mathematics. Corry has insightfully indicated what this meant from Hilbert to Bourbaki.89 Later, topologists such as Alexander Grothendieck, Robert Langlands, Raoul Bott, Michael Atiyah, Vladimir Arnold, and Yuri Manin, were indeed motivated by a desire of “unifying” mathematics, and Wiles with his proof of Fermat’s conjecture presents an outstanding specific example.90

The belief that firm mathematical foundations stabilize physical theories and that underlying quantum field theories and string theory is a self-consistent mathematical framework yet to be created, is what motivates the physicists. Conversely, a number of mathematical geometric objects, structures, and notions can be formulated in terms of quantum field theories and strings, and the physicists’ non-rigorous techniques provide (and provided) deep novel insights, insights that are not or were not evident from an internal mathematical perspective. In fact, the mathematicians and physicists at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton devoted the academic year 1996–97 to teach a small group of mathematicians the basic physical concepts of quantum field theory and string theory. The goal was “to create and convey an understanding of some fundamental notions of physics, such as quantum field theory, supersymmetry and string theory…[with an] emphasis on developing the intuition stemming from functional integrals.”91 There is no better indication of the new symbiosis than Pierre Deligne et al.’s Quantum Fields and Strings: A Course for Mathematicians, the two volumes containing the lectures given during that year.92

In addition to the above developments, the practice of theoretical physics also became deeply transformed in the 1970s by remarkable advances in computers and computing.93 The accuracy of the field theoretic calculations required for the interpretation of the precise data that the novel techniques and instrumentation in atomic physics had produced was indicated in Kinoshita’s talk at Shelter Island II. The early 1980s measurements by Hans Dehmelt and others of the magnetic moment of the electron and of the muon required the evaluation of eighth-order Feynman diagrams. The same kind of calculational precision was demanded of some of the QCD calculations to interpret the data generated by the then operating accelerators and detectors.

In 1974, Kenneth Wilson initiated a symmetry-preserving, non-perturbative study of Yang-Mills theory by approximating it on a lattice, the lattice spacing a acting as an ultraviolet cutoff. With this symmetry preserving regularization procedure, both low and high energy observables could be computed.94 This led to a great deal of activity at the formal level,95 as well as extensive numeral studies of hadronic properties,96 which have extended Monte Carlo methods.97 It has thus become possible to calculate with remarkable precision the mass difference between proton and neutron.98 It also resulted in a strong interaction between quantum field theory and statistical mechanics.

Computers have made possible simulations of complex systems—such as a neutron or a proton when described by QCD, or the structure of complex biomolecules described by density functional methods—that would be impossible otherwise. Simulations allow not only the explorations of models of complex systems based on laboratory-manipulable entities but also the explorations of possible worlds such as might result from the merger of a black holes and a neutron star.99 They have thus enlarged immeasurably our conception of the world.100

Until the 1970s, physics was traditionally divided into theoretical and experimental physics.101 As a consequence of the spectacular increase in computer power and also the possibility of constructing computers making use of quantum logic, a new branch of physics, computational physics, was established in the 1980s with all the accoutrements that go with a new discipline: journals, professorships, prizes, etc. Computational physics deals with computer simulations and these keep on playing a continually increasing important role in all the sciences.

In concluding this introduction, I want to stress that although I am focusing on the two Shelter Island conferences and attaching great importance to both of them, Shelter Island II was neither a watershed nor a turning point in theoretical ideas in the way Shelter Island I was. Rather, Shelter Island II highlighted some of the deep changes that were occurring. It indicated that a new era in “fundamental” physics had begun with the recognition on the one hand, of the richness of non-abelian gauge theories, and on the other, of the limitations of the standard model and of all local quantum field theories, so that both big bang cosmology and string theory, though highly speculative, were novel features to be taken seriously.

Shelter Island II also indicated the transformation of high energy theoretical physics at the sociological level: a new, younger generation of theorists was taking over the intellectual leadership of the community, a generation that had experienced the upheavals of the 1960s and the 1970s: the civil rights movements, and in particular, the university students’ protests. These protests had raised fundamental questions about authority. The students raised questions about their civil and political rights, about the authoritarian character of universities, about the civil and political rights of blacks, about the reasons and aims of the war in Vietnam, and about the authoritarian character of social institutions more generally.102 And the protests were global. The witnessing of, or participating in the students’ protests by the members of the generation taking over the intellectual leadership of high energy physics is reflected in their stance regarding authority: they were ready to question everything.103

For the young theorists, there was another corollary connected with having witnessed or having taken part in the student rebellion: the desire to have their theoretical physics “pure” and not of or in service to the military-industrial complex. This resonated with the component of the mathematical community that likewise wanted their mathematics to be pure—and not “applied” in any way.104

It is interesting to compare Shelter Island II with another conference, the Royal Society Discussion Meeting held on May 25–26, 1983, a few days before Shelter Island II. “The Constants of Physics” were the focus of the Discussion Meeting, a conference that had been organized by William McCrea, Martin Rees, and Steven Weinberg. In his introductory remarks McCrea stated: “What distinguishes modern physics from classical physics is the recognition of the role of fundamental (or universal) constants. Mathematical [read theoretical] physics must be formulated so as to admit such constants; that is what distinguishes it from other applied mathematics. It is the particular values actually possessed by the constants that make our universe what it is. Some analysis of this whole situation is the theme of this Discussion…. The domain is one in which observation and theory are inseparable.”105 After pointing to the important role that contingency and context play in the formulation of physical theories McCrea noted:
At any point in our deliberations, it therefore seems inevitable that we should speak in terms of some definite theoretical model of the world of experience. There appears, however, to be no meaning in supposing there exists a unique final model that we are trying to discover. We construct a model, we do not discover it.
Is it nevertheless true to say that models lead to the discovery of constants of physics? The answer seems to be yes, in the sense that a model may suggest a set of operations that is found to lead to the ‘determination’ of some constant.106

It is this Bridgmanian operational view of physics that determined the structure of the program of the discussion.107 The opening talks were by K. F. Smith and by B. W. Petley on the definition and the measurement of the fundamental constants; by M. Goldhaber on the search for proton decay and other rare phenomena; by R. D. Reasenberg on the constancy of G, the gravitational constant; by J. M. Irvine on the limits on the variability of coupling constant from the Oklo natural reactor; and by B. E. J. Pagel on the implications of quasar spectroscopy for the constancy of constants. There were then talks on the most “foundational” theoretical models: by S. Weinberg on the theoretical prospects for understanding the values of fundamental constants; by C. H. Llewllyn Smith on the standard model; by S. Adler on Einstein’s theory of general relativity considered as a long-wavelength effective field theory; by J. Ellis on the attempt to formulate models beyond the standard model, models that unify the strong, electroweak, and gravitational forces; and by H. B. Nielsen on field theories without “fundamental” gauge symmetries. The next set of talks were concerned with the early universe: T. W. B. Kibble on phase transitions in the early universe; S. W. Hawking on the cosmological constant; and M. J. Rees on large numbers and ratios in astrophysics and cosmology. The next two talks were of a more general character but anchored in and concerned with observable phenomena: by W. H. Press and A. P. Lightman on the dependence of macrophysical phenomena on the values of the fundamental constants; and by J. D. Barrow on the dependence of phenomena on the dimensionality of space-time. The final talk by D. Carter addressed a subject that had recently obtained a great deal of attention: the anthropic principle.

The principal organizers—McCrea and Rees—and the speakers at the Royal Society Discussion were all members of an older generation than that associated with Shelter Island II.108 It was also held under the auspices of the Royal Society and thus reflected the conservative aspects of the British scientific culture, in particular regarding the relation of theory to experiment and observation. All the talks at the Royal Society Discussion made reference to, and close contact with, existing findings from experimental and observational physics. In contrast, roughly half of the Shelter Island II non-historical presentations were concerned with the relation of physics to recent important developments in mathematics.

The intent of my survey from Shelter Island I to Shelter Island II is to point to the aforementioned deep transformations of the metaphysics of theoretical physics, and, for an important segment of the high energy community, of the changes in their practice. I want to emphasize that at best I will have “pointed to.” Much else was going on that I only briefly refer to: supersymmetry, the beginnings of string theory, the consideration of the possibility of space-time having twenty-six or ten or eleven dimensions, quantum gravity, etc. I am neither fully cognizant nor competent to present the richness and the complexity of what was being accomplished.109 A fine-grained, detailed, scholarly account of all these developments, of the context in which they took place, of the individuals and institutions responsible for the advances, and an assessment of their impact remains to be narrated by historians possessing a mastery of the technical issues involved. Some of it is being, or has been, done, for example, Hoddeson et al. on the genesis of the standard model; Galison on the experimental cultures of high energy physics110; O’Raifeartaigh on the history and evolution of gauge theories111; Freedman and van Nieuwenhuizen112 and Zumino113 with an internalist history of supersymmetry; Schwarz114 and Cappelli et al. on aspects of the genesis of string theory115; and Galison on the impact of string theory.116

As the present article was being submitted to Physics in Perspective, I was sent117 a copy of Gerard ’t Hooft, “The Evolution of Quantum Field Theory, from QED to Grand Unification.”118 It is a masterful, detailed history of the developments referred to in its title, narrated by one of the principal contributors to the acceptance of non-abelian quantum field theories—both electroweak theory and QCD. It is what traditionally is called an “internal” history. My aim has been different. I have tried, given my limited knowledge of the technical advances, to adumbrate the transformation in “foundational” assumptions these developments have implied.

Section1.Heading: Shelter Island I Revisited
Section1.Para: The Shelter Island I conference took place from June 2 to 4, 1947, at the Ram’s Head Inn on Shelter Island at the tip of Long Island. I have elsewhere narrated how Shelter Island I came to be.119 Here I only want to make a few remarks concerning the sociology of Shelter Island I and also to report on the new light that has been shed on what happened at Shelter Island I by the recent discovery of the detailed notes that Hans Bethe took at the conference.120

The dominant figures at Shelter Island I were the physicists responsible for the wartime developments of radar and of the atomic bomb: J. Robert Oppenheimer, Hans Bethe, John von Neumann, Isidor I. Rabi, Bruno Rossi, Robert Serber, Edward Teller, George Uhlenbeck, Victor Weisskopf, and John Archibald Wheeler. Also invited to the conference were some of the younger physicists they considered outstanding—Julian Schwinger, Richard Feynman, David Bohm, Robert Marshak, Arnold Nordsieck, Herman Feshbach, Willis Lamb, and Abraham Pais—who all, except for Pais, had worked at Los Alamos, or at the Columbia, MIT, or Berkeley Rad Labs during the war. Gregory Breit, Linus Pauling, John van Vleck, and Karl Darrow were invited because of their seniority. There were no women among the participants.

Except for Hendrik Kramers, who was in the United States because he was the chair of the technical committee helping the United Nations formulate a plan for the international control of atomic energy, and Abraham Pais, who was a member of the Institute for Advanced Study and had made some recent important contributions to elucidating the self-energy problem in quantum field theory, only American physicists were invited. In fact, Frank Jewett, the head of the National Academy of Science, the institution that sponsored the conference, Duncan McInness, who formulated the idea of the conference, and Karl Darrow, the secretary of the American Physical Society who had helped organize the conference, all wanted the conference to marshal the power of American physics to address and solve the most pressing problems in fundamental physics, just as it had solved urgent and deeply consequential wartime problems. All three wanted the conference to demonstrate that theoretical physics in the United States had come into its own with the “younger men” who had been born and trained there. The conference was to prove the strength of American theoretical physics not only in wartime activities, but also in “pure” physics.

Shelter Island I and the two subsequent conferences it engendered (the Pocono and Oldstone conferences) were small, closed, and elitist in spirit. In a sense, they mark the postponed end of an era, that of the 1930s, and its characteristic style of doing physics: small groups and small budgets, as in the case of the Washington Conferences of Theoretical Physics. None cost more than $1500.

What the newly found notes that Bethe took at Shelter Island I corroborate, and in fact amplify, is what Darrow had recorded in his notes on the conference: the overwhelming dominance of Oppenheimer in all matters, be they technical, intellectual, or administrative. The notes also gives valuable details of the presentations. On the first day of the conference, Lamb presented the most recent data of his experiment with Robert Retherford that measured the energy difference between the 2s1/2 and 2p1/2 levels in hydrogen. His robust data established that contrary to the solutions of the Dirac equation for the energy levels of an electron in a Coulomb field, the 2s and 2p levels of the hydrogen atom are not degenerate, but that the 2s level shifted [is] up by about 0.037cm−1 (1100 Mc).” In the discussion that followed Lamb’s presentation, Oppenheimer pointed out that if one calculated the difference between the 2p and 2s energy levels using hole theory a finite answer might be obtained, given that the divergences encountered were logarithmically divergent (see figure 2).

Lamb’s talk was followed by Rabi’s, who presented the data John Nafe, Edward Nelson, and he had obtained on the hyperfine structure of hydrogen and deuterium. That afternoon, Rossi reported on the experiment that had been carried out in Rome by Conversi, Pancini, and Piccioni on the absorption of mesons in the atmosphere.

The entire morning session of the second day of the conference was devoted to Kramers’s extensive presentation of his version of the Lorentz theory of an extended charge, in which structural effects were encapsulated in the experimental mass of the charged particle. This was work that he had done in the late 1930s, and that his students had carried out in the early 1940s.121 He concentrated on the classical version of his non-relativistic theory, though Bethe’s notes make clear that in the last part of his talk he indicated what quantizing the theory would do (see figure 3).
