During the afternoon of the second day, Weisskopf reviewed the divergence difficulties in the hole theory calculations of the self-energy of an electron. In a paper that he had written in 1939, he had indicated that in hole theory the divergence would be logarithmic to all orders of perturbation theory and (according to Breit’s notes of Shelter Island I) Weisskopf agreed with Oppenheimer’s hunch that a hole theoretic calculation of the difference in the 2p and 2s energy levels would not diverge. During the ensuing discussion, Weisskopf and Schwinger indicated how a hole-theoretic calculation of the level shift might be attempted and suggested further reasons why a finite result might result from the applications of Kramers’s ideas.

On the third day of the conference, Oppenheimer, in an extensive presentation, indicated the problems raised by the Conversi, Pancini, and Piccioni experiment. That experiment indicated that the meson detected in cosmic ray showers near the surface of the earth could not be the meson postulated by Yukawa to be responsible for the nuclear forces between nucleons, whether the meson theories are treated perturbatively or non-perturbatively as in the Oppenheimer-Schwinger strong coupling approach of the late 1930s. The ensuing discussion gave rise to the Marshak and Bethe paper in which the Marshak two-meson hypothesis was formulated.122 Marshak suggested that there were two kinds of mesons. The heavier ones were produced at the top of the atmosphere by cosmic rays in nuclear reactions. He identified these with the mesons Yukawa had postulated. The π-mesons then decay into the lighter µ mesons, which do not interact strongly with nuclei.123

After the conference was over, Bethe performed his famous non-relativistic calculation on the train ride from New York to Schenectady. The paper in which he proved that the level shift would be accounted for by quantum electrodynamics was completed by June 9 and thereafter circulated to the participants of the Shelter Island conference. In his paper, Bethe acknowledged in a footnote the comments by Weisskopf and Schwinger that a hole-theoretic calculation of energy level differences would be finite.124 Their insight justified the high-energy cutoff he introduced in his calculation.

But in his paper Bethe did not acknowledge Kramers’s talk even though Kramers’s presentation had been very important by stressing the importance of expressing observables in terms of the experimental mass of the electron. That Kramers’s talk was influential not only by virtue of his “philosophical” standpoint but also by virtue of its technical components is reflected in the fact that his use of the Hertz potential and his derivation of the potential that the dressed electron with experimental mass experiences became the point of departure of Schwinger in his quantum electrodynamic calculation of the magnetic moment of the electron and of the Lamb shift. Moreover, at Shelter Island II, Weisskopf recalled that in 1939 both he and Kramers were lecturers at the Michigan Summer School. In one of their conversations, the recent paper by Pasternack,125 in which he reviewed all the high precision spectroscopic work that had been done on the 2s level of hydrogen and had concluded that the 2s level lies higher than the 2p level, came up. Kramers had told him then: “You younger people should calculate the difference between the energy of the hydrogen 2s state and the free electron. Both are infinite, and you should take the difference, which is hopefully finite, and that may be the Pasternack effect.”126 Kramers had been the reason for French and Weisskopf stating their hole theory calculation of the 2s-2p energy difference in 1946, before Shelter Island I and before they had knowledge of Lamb and Retherford’s results. It is interesting to note that at Shelter Island II, Bethe did interject during Lamb’s talk that Kramers had “inspired him.”

Bethe probably did not acknowledge Kramers’s presentation in his paper because Bethe thought that he had a much simpler way than Kramers to incorporate Kramers’s insight. Bethe had noted that the self-energy of a free non-relativistic electron calculated quantum electrodynamically could be considered an electromagnetic mass of the electron—and though divergent—was to be added to the mechanical mass of the electron. The only meaningful statements of the theory involve the sum of the electromagnetic and mechanical masses, which combination is to be identified as the experimental mass of a free electron. In contrast to Kramers’s approach, Bethe’s was a model-independent formulation of mass renormalization that did not assume an extended charge distribution to the electron. And in contrast to Schwinger and Weisskopf’s initial insight that a hole-theoretic calculation that computed the difference between the energies of two levels would be finite, Bethe’s mass renormalization allowed computing the energy of each level and gave an unambiguous formulation of mass renormalization in the non-relativistic case. Moreover, he knew what was required to formulate an analogous relativistic prescription. Weisskopf and Schwinger, though emphasizing Kramers’s insight, could not do so at Shelter Island.

Dresden, in his biography of Kramers, claimed that Kramers did not receive adequate credit for his contributions at Shelter Island.127 Bethe’s Shelter Island notes confirm that he was right.128 Here is an example of the Matthew effect at work.

To Bethe, the pragmatist for whom numbers were always the criterion of good physics and who at Los Alamos had just been deeply and successfully involved in the war effort calculating numbers that translated into physical effects and measurable empirical data, the challenge was to get the numbers out and account for the magnitude of the 2p-2s shift in hydrogen and for the new values of the hyperfine splitting in hydrogen and deuterium that Nafe, Nelson, and Rabi had measured. Accounting for the empirical data would become evidence for the correctness of the theory, or at least for the model that approximated it. Kramers’s approach was too model dependent, too theoretical and too far removed from calculating numbers. For Bethe, the value of a novel idea was gauged by whether it could help you calculate numbers that could be compared with empirical data.

Bethe’s calculation was crucial. By introducing the concept of mass renormalization and its associated meaning in the simple manner he had, and indicating how it is to be used in the case of a bound electron, Bethe’s calculation gave a new perspective on how to address quantum electrodynamical calculations and obtain numbers that could be compared with experimental data. Furthermore, Bethe could convincingly justify the cutoffs he had to introduce in his non-relativistic calculation and obtain a logarithmic expression for the Lamb shift that agreed with the observed level shift. It should be added that only Bethe could have evaluated the logarithmic contribution as quickly as he did. He had encountered similar logarithmic expressions when calculating quantum mechanically the energy loss of fast charged particle traversing matter in his Habilitationschrift in 1929.

Schwinger made another crucial calculation, perhaps a more influential one than Bethe’s, by calculating the quantum electrodynamic contribution to the magnetic moment of the Dirac electron. His calculation was crucial because it was the first field theoretical perturbative calculation of quantum electrodynamic radiative corrections that was Lorentz and gauge invariant. Up to this point all calculations had been based on hole theory.

Hole theory was not gauge invariant because the vacuum subtraction prescription labeled states according to p and only p − eA and not p is gauge invariant.129 The lack of gauge invariance led to arbitrariness and difficulties in all the prewar calculations. It already arose in the calculation of the electron self energy in lowest order of perturbation theory. The self-energy was divergent, but introducing a cutoff for the possible momenta p to obtain finite results destroyed the Lorentz invariance of the theory.

Schwinger’s calculation indicated that a gauge and Lorentz invariant quantum field theoretic description of both electrons and radiation could be formulated, and that with it one could calculate observable consequences.

Shelter Island I was a landmark whose impact was comparable to that of the Solvay Congress of 1911, which set the stage for all the subsequent developments in quantum theory by virtue of Planck’s and Einstein’s interpretations of the precise measurements of black body radiation as a function of temperature. Similarly, Shelter Island I provided the initial stimulus for the post–World War II developments in quantum field theory—renormalization theory, effective, relativistically invariant computational methods, Feynman diagrams—by virtue of Lamb and Retherford’s experiment on the fine structure of hydrogen and Nafe, Nelson, and Rabi’s experiment on the hyperfine structure of hydrogen. The conference was also responsible for the elucidation of the structure of the mesonic component of cosmic rays.

The Shelter Island, Pocono, and Oldstone conferences were the precursors of the Rochester Conferences on High Energy Physics.130 But they differed from these later conferences in important ways. The Rochester conferences were more professional, international, and democratic and had the imprint of the new era: the large group efforts and the large budgets involved in machine physics.131 Also, whereas Shelter Island and Pocono looked upon QED as a self-contained discipline, the Rochester conferences saw “particle physics” come into its own, with QED as one of its subfields—albeit one with a privileged, paradigmatic position.

Section1.Heading: From Shelter Island I to Shelter Island II
Section1.Para: After World War II, physicists in the United States became admired and lavishly rewarded for their wartime efforts. The identification of physics with material and military elements of national security—radar, computers, transistors, nuclear weaponry—had given them power. The United States did not suffer the physical destruction the war had wreaked on Europe, the Soviet Union, and Japan. So after the war it prospered economically from the industrial goods it could readily manufacture and from the access to cheap Middle Eastern oil that it had obtained from Great Britain in return for its Lend-Lease help during the war. The Servicemen’s Readjustment Act of 1944, usually referred to as the GI Bill, granted returning veterans tuition and living expenses to continue their education and resulted in universities, and their physics and engineering departments in particular, to expand dramatically. Research contracts by the armed forces and by the AEC made it possible for physics departments to support large numbers of research assistants and postdoctoral fellows. Several generations of outstanding physicists were trained as a result of this expansion. The magnitude of the enterprise is reflected in the fact that an average of 500 PhDs in physics were awarded annually by American universities from 1950 to 1960. The number of physics PhDs granted in 1970 climbed to 1500. It declined considerably thereafter with the sharp curtailment of governmental funds to universities that reflected the upheaval brought about by the civil rights movement, the Vietnam War, the student protest movements, and the Republican party gaining extended control of the presidency, of the Congress, and of the state legislatures. The 1970s marked the beginning of a deep change in the political and economic structure of the United States. Neoliberalism began assuming a dominant role in shaping economic policy, globalization deeply changed the structure of commerce and industry, fundamentalism began playing a more vociferous and influential role in shaping the political agenda as reflected in the limitations on teaching evolution in public schools, and a distrust of scientific expertise and of science more generally became apparent. The cancellation of the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) in 1993 is perhaps the clearest indication of the public’s disenchantment with high energy physics, and with “fundamental” science more generally.132

Shelter Island II is part of that story. It owes its existence to Rockefeller University’s response to what was happening during the 1970s. The Rockefeller Institute was founded in 1901 and was to be, and until 1959 was, devoted entirely to medical and biomedical research. In 1959, it started graduate programs leading to the PhD in various disciplines in the natural sciences and in 1965 renamed itself Rockefeller University. A PhD program in physics was established in the early 1960s. In the late 1970s, in the wake of governmental cutbacks for research in the sciences and the changing national political and socio-economic context, Rockefeller University reconsidered its expansion and closed various PhD programs. Shelter Island II, which was held in June 1983, thirty-six years after Shelter Island I, was organized by Nicola Khuri, a highly respected theoretical physicist and a professor at Rockefeller University,133 in part to substantiate the value and importance of the physics program to the university.

The difference in economic, social, political, and cultural contexts is one of the sharp contrasts between Shelter Island I and II. Another is the size and cost of the two conferences. Some twenty-five scientists attended Shelter Island I and its total cost was less than $1,500, all paid for by the National Academy of Sciences. Over a hundred theoretical physicists were invited to Shelter Island II, and some sixty attended. Its budget was roughly $100,000, with many of the attendees paying their own expenses. The rest of the expenses were covered by contributions from the Richard Lounsbery Foundation, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the Texaco Philanthropic Foundation, and by Susan B. Borden. Rockefeller University did not contribute any funds. The ravages of inflation are illustrated by the fact that the expenditure to accommodate all the twenty-five participants of Shelter Island I for one night at the comfortable and elegant Ram’s Head Inn, where the conference took place, was $200. At Shelter Island I, the average per diem cost per person was $20; at Shelter Island II it was $80.

The subsequent detection of the Ws, the Z, the top and bottom quarks, and in 2012 of the Higgs boson, anchored the standard model as the effective field theory describing subnuclear phenomena up to the 1 TeV scale.

Gell-Mann’s opening lecture at Shelter Island II—entitled “From Renormalizability to Calculability?”—summarized what had been accomplished with the standard model, indicated the ambiguities connected with the Higgs bosons (“how many?”), characterized some the shortcomings of the standard model, and discussed some of the attempts to go beyond the standard model: Grand Unified Theories (GUTs), supersymmetry,135 and string theories. The lectures at Shelter Island II gave presentations of these new paths being charted to overcome the limitations of local relativistic quantum field theories and of the standard model.
But before turning to these technical aspects let me narrate the events that led to Shelter Island II.

Section1.Heading: The Genesis of Shelter Island II

Section2.Heading: Rockefeller University
Section2.Para: The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research was established in 1901, during the period when philanthropies by the “robber barons” founded colleges, universities, museums, and other such public institutions.136 At the urging of Rev. Frederick Gates, the Baptist minister who was to guide John D. Rockefeller Sr.’s philanthropy and who had noted that his “fortune is rolling up like an avalanche!” and that he “must distribute it faster than it grows! If … not, it will crush you and your children and your children’s children!,” Rockefeller endowed the University of Chicago in 1890, the Rockefeller Institute a decade later, and the Rockefeller Foundation in 1913. The Rockefeller Institute was to devote itself to biological and medical research as an independent institution not attached to any university nor to any hospital.137 Under Simon Flexner’s directorship from 1903 to 1935, it attracted an outstanding research staff and became recognized as being one of the preeminent institutions in innovative and generative applications of biochemistry and the physical sciences to biology and to medicine. After World War II, under the leadership of Detlev Bronk, the Rockefeller Institute transformed from a research institute to a graduate university in the natural sciences. In 1954, its charter was changed to give it the right to confer the degrees of PhD and of Doctor of Medical Sciences. In 1964, it changed its name to Rockefeller University and became then (and has remained) the only institution in the United States calling itself a university that grants only doctorates. Its eminence as a university is indicated by the fact that in 1965 its senior faculty, which consisted of some forty full professors and ten emeriti, included three Nobel laureates, and that thirty-six of the faculty were members of the National Academy of Sciences.

By 1965, a modern nine-story building costing $3.5 million had been built to accommodate the laboratories and offices of its 300 junior and senior faculty members and its 118 graduate students, and to house in some eighty rooms the stalls and cages for the 20,000 mice, 3000 guinea pigs and the dozens of opossums and minks used by the faculty and students for research. In addition, several other buildings had been erected: one to house a large auditorium, one for graduate student apartments, and another, the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Hall, was to function as a social and residential center for visiting scientists.138

The Rockefeller faculty was among the highest paid in the US and all the graduate students were holding full fellowships paying at least $3500 per annum. Furthermore, almost all of the expenditures connected with the research carried out by the faculty and by the graduate students were paid for by the university. At the time, the university could easily afford these expenditures. The value of its investments amounted to over $200 million and the return from them covered its operating budget of $8.1 million, which included the research expenditures. In fact, the return from the endowment had allowed $1.3 million to be put in reserve during 1965.

The special character of the university that Detlev Bronk imparted to it can be gleaned from the structure of the commencement exercises he oversaw. He would make brief opening and closing remarks, and in place of a commencement address members of the faculty would review the accomplishments of the graduates. Thus, in 1961, when some ten students received their degree, among them two women, Bronk commented: “No public figure speaks at length of his concerns nor tells of his proposals for a better world as is often the case on these occasions. We will not boast of our accomplishments. The achievements to be mentioned are those of the our graduates.”139 In transforming itself into a university, the disciplines in which PhD degrees were granted were expanded, but the administrative structure was not changed. No departments were formed. Professors were hired on an individual basis and given funds with which to run their laboratories, which were administered like fiefdoms. Junior faculty members were attached to a particular laboratory and its professor. In 1961, George Uhlenbeck accepted a professorship in physics, and his presence helped recruit Theodore Berlin (1961),140 Ezekiel G. D. Cohen (1963), Abraham Pais (1964),141 and Nicholas Khuri (1964). Mark Kac, an eminent mathematician, joined the university in 1962.142 Similarly, Donald Davidson, Joel Feinberg, Harry G. Frankfurt, and Saul A. Kripke, all four outstanding philosophers, were hired.

In 1968, Detlev Bronk retired as president of the university143 and was succeeded by Frederick Seitz, who had been a member of the board of trustees for the previous four years. Bronk and Seitz had known each other for a long time. Throughout the postwar period they both were members of various high-level science advisory bodies to the government. Seitz had succeeded Bronk as president of the National Academy of Sciences (NAS),144 and throughout his presidency he was in close contact with Bronk in connection with NAS matters.145 Under Seitz’s leadership, the NAS, which has the responsibility of giving technical advise to the federal government, shed its reluctance to be actively engaged in shaping policy relating to scientific and technological issues. Seitz was deeply involved in the formation of the nationwide consortium of universities that administered the 200 GeV accelerator that the Atomic Energy Commission had underwritten at what became the Fermi National Laboratory in Weston, Illinois. During Seitz’s presidency, the NAS initiated the creation of the National Academy of Engineering, as well as several other institutions and agencies to advise the government on technical issues.146

Daniel Greenberg, in his article in Science reporting on the appointment of Seitz as president of Rockefeller University, noted that:
it was no secret that Seitz and some of the Academy’s elders have been feuding over Seitz’s close ties with the Pentagon and his belief that the Academy should have no reservations about making its resources available to the military… But there is no evidence that these differences ever reached disruptive proportions or that they played any part in Seitz’s decision to go to Rockefeller. Though the Academy is probably too unwieldy and tradition-encrusted to become an important instrument of political concern, many of its members have of late taken to affixing their names to political statements of one sort or another, especially petitions opposing the administration’s long-standing Vietnam policies. It is doubtful that political attitudes will figure large in the selection of a successor to Seitz, but it is also doubtful that the membership will be altogether docile on this score.147

Already at the first commencement exercises over which he presided (1969), Seitz revealed his conservative inclinations. By then, the number of students receiving their PhD degrees had grown to twenty-seven. At the same time, most of the campuses in the United States were experiencing the opposition of students to the war in Vietnam and to the intrusion and deep influence of the military-industrial complex in the research activities of universities. Many of the Rockefeller graduating students were members of a student organization that was actively engaged in opposing the Vietnam War and the funding by Congress of the Safeguard anti-ballistic missile (ABM) and wore buttons on their gown that stated in large letters “Stop ABM.” Evidently many among them had proposed to Seitz that this commencement be devoted what Seitz later characterized as matters “more socially important and relevant than science.”

Breaking with the university’s tradition, Seitz indicated at the commencement that the students’ request was received too late for it to be acted upon by the faculty as a whole and that the “few faculty members he did consult were not enthusiastic.” And he concluded his remarks by indicating that he believed science to be very relevant to human history and that “open discussion…is indeed an obligation or solemn duty in the proper occasion of which this is certainly one.”148

Seitz’s tenure as president of Rockefeller was difficult. He had to confront and address the financial pressures that resulted from US involvement in Vietnam and to rethink, because of the emerging financial constraints, the university’s expansion beyond the natural sciences. When Seitz took office the stock market had fallen sharply, resulting in a sizable reduction of the university’s endowment and additionally, inflation had markedly decreased the value of its returns. Adding to these difficulties was the fact that a seventeen story research “tower” was under construction whose cost had originally been estimated to be around $38 million and was being paid for largely by endowment funds. Inflation was augmenting its costs markedly, and inflation was increasing the expenditures for all university operations. Furthermore, in the early 1970s there was a sharp curtailment of government funding with federal research and training grants becoming much harder to get, putting further demands on the university’s resources. In consequence, the university began running an annual deficit, which in 1974 (the year after the Arab oil embargo) amounted to $2.2 million.

The Board of Trustees’ and Seitz’s response to the new financial realities was to rethink the university’s commitment to have PhD programs in disciplines outside the natural sciences. Thus, in 1974, Albert Gold, the university’s vice president for academic resources, with Seitz‘s approval, held separate, informal, and unofficial conversations with the four philosophy professors, Davidson, Frankfurt, Feinberg, and Kripke. He told them that a “significant number of members of the faculty and of the board of trustees felt that the ‘experiment’ with philosophy at Rockefeller had failed,” but indicated that “Seitz was committed to the principle of tenure and would support the philosophers as long as he held his office.” But he noted that “Seitz was approaching retirement age and in view of the prevailing attitude toward the discipline and future uncertainties, they might think about moving.”149 Starting already in 1972, no graduate students in philosophy were being accepted and no junior faculty member in philosophy was being promoted, nor was a replacement being hired when a junior faculty’s appointment ended.

At first, the philosophers believed that this was happening because of the austerity measures Seitz had imposed, but they came to realize that the administration was sending them an unambiguous message. They thought of taking legal action and to ask the American Association of University Professors to intervene on their behalf, but decided against it and hired a lawyer to enter into negotiations with the university. Since each one of them received an invitation to join the philosophy department at an outstanding university,150 they accepted the administration’s offer to pay them three years of salary and retirement benefits and left. Kripke, who was dragging his feet and was the last of the four to come to terms with the situation, received a letter from Seitz in July 1976 stating that “the philosophy program was being terminated and that after another academic year and with the salary payments accepted by his colleagues his ‘appointment will be deemed to expire.’” At that same time, Seitz wrote to the logicians Hao Wang and Donald Martin that in the future the university would not be a very attractive place for them to work, and “proposed” to Wang, who was a tenured professor, that in the coming months he “investigate alternate posts at other universities.”151 Seitz withdrew his letters to Kripke after he received severe criticisms from the faculty on his handling of the negotiation and the possibility of having dismissed tenured members of the faculty. Seitz had been alerted to the tenure issue by the faculty members on the committee he had set up to advise him on university priorities. They had stressed that if the university were to “concentrate” its degree programs in the biomedical sciences this would have to be done by attrition and not by dismissal. Shortly after receiving the letter from Seitz, Kripke decided to accept the university’s offer and departed. The question of whether tenure had been abrogated thus remained unresolved.

Seitz and the board of trustees had in fact accepted the recommendation of the committee on university priorities that the university promote and cultivate only disciplines that contribute directly to the life sciences, those being the central concern of the institution. Seitz and the board were evidently ready not only to dismiss the philosophers and logicians, but to go further in phasing out the “ancillary disciplines.” However, the furor over the way the severance of the philosophers had been handled forestalled further “concentration” by drastic means.152

What was happening at Rockeller University made the Sunday, September 26, 1976, edition of the New York Times. The three column wide headline on the front page stated in large print: “Rockefeller University Hit by Storm over Tenure.” In the opening paragraphs Israel Shenker, the reporter who covered the story,153 indicated that “a summer storm over tenure has produced perhaps the greatest embarrassment in the institution’s 75-year history. The philosophy group—with men of world reputation—is being shut down. Logic professors154—hardly less distinguished are being encouraged to leave. Other professors are finding that their research support is being threatened. Bearing the brunt of the storm is Dr. Frederick Seitz, who is being attacked for his maladroitness in forcing people out to save money.”155 The severance of the philosophers marked the end of the evolution of the university into the ideal that Bronk had envisioned. It was clear that the university would no longer consider expanding with programs in the social sciences and the humanities. In fact, it was not clear how the groups not in the mainstream of the life sciences would fare in the future.

The Board of Trustees did formally affirm that “the long term policy whereby a tenured faculty member is assured of the security of his academic position and salary, and freedom to pursue his scholarly interests whatever they may be” stood and would not be altered. It also conveyed informal assurances to the mathematicians, physicists, and logicians that their jobs were secure. But given what had happened they were apprehensive about what would happen to their programs in the future.

Roman Jackiw, who spent the 1977–78 academic year at Rockefeller University as a visiting professor, recalls that at that time there was a great deal of concern and worry among the physicists about their program, and also a good deal of talk how they—in contrast to the philosophers—would resist attempts to close the program. One of the principal reasons for Shelter Island II coming into being was to prove to the Rockefeller administration the importance of its physics program and prevent the possibility of a sharp reduction in the size of the physics programs.

In 1978, upon Seitz’s retirement, Joshua Lederberg was named president of Rockefeller University. Patrick Haggerty, the chairman of the university’s board of trustees, in making the announcement described Lederberg as a “pioneer” in his field of research, bacterial genetics, and emphasized his “deep concern for strengthening communications between science and the society it serves.” Lederberg had been awarded the Nobel Prize in 1958, when he was thirty-three years old, for his research indicating that bacteria could exchange genetic information during a phase of their reproduction that could be considered sexual and could also do so with the help of viruses of a process he and Norton Zinder called transduction. Lederberg had obtained his BS from Columbia University in 1941, and after serving in the army had earned his PhD from Yale in 1947. Thereafter he accepted a position in the University of Wisconsin’s department of genetics. In 1957, he helped found and became the chairman of the department of medical genetics in the university’s medical school. In 1959, he accepted the chairmanship of the department of genetics of Stanford University’s School of Medicine. He there further developed his interests and competence in computing, in artificial intelligence and in bioinformatics.156

Section2.Heading: The Genesis of the Conference
Section2.Para: In 1982, Nicola Khuri, one of the professors of physics at the university, felt that holding an international conference on the foundations of fundamental physics attended by the leading theorists in the field would indicate to the university’s administration the respect the physics group commanded internationally and the value of its presence on the campus, and would thus help anchor theoretical physics at Rockefeller. The reasons for holding such a conference at Shelter Island were twofold. Khuri’s wife descended from a Quaker family, which had come to Massachusetts in the seventeenth century and had been driven out of the Puritan settlement because of their religious beliefs. They had migrated to the eastern tip of Long Island, which became known as Shelter Island. Khuri’s wife had grown up on the island and the Khuris owned a summer home there. The second, more professional reason was that the conference could memorialize the 1947 Shelter Island Conference, which had been a landmark in the history of theoretical physics.

In the summer of 1982, Khuri approached Rod Nichols,157 the executive vice president of the university, to explore his reaction to have Rockefeller University sponsor such a conference. He also contacted Seitz to enlist his help about possible funding of such a conference. The reaction of both of them being positive, in September, Khuri wrote the letter to Lederberg reproduced in figure 4 below.158 A few days later, on October 4, Lederberg sent Khuri a note, stating: “More than pleased, I am happy to endorse your proposal, and proud to have the Rockefeller University take the part you suggest in sponsoring the conference.”
Fig. 4
Nikola Khuri’s letter to Joshua Lederberg proposing that Rockefeller University sponsor Shelter Island II. Credit: Courtesy of Nicola Khuri.

Upon receiving Lederberg’s note, Khuri formed an organizing committee consisting of Stephen Adler, Roman Jackiw, Abdus Salam, Steven Weinberg, Edward Witten, and himself. They agreed that the conference would be devoted to “Quantum Field Theory and Fundamental Problems in Physics.” By mid-October, Khuri had drafted a letter to the participants of Shelter Island I. All the surviving participants of Shelter Island I, Bethe, Weisskopf, Rabi, Serber, Marshak, Lamb, Pais, Schwinger, Feynman, Teller, Uhlenbeck, Pauling, and Bohm, were invited. All of them attended, except Teller, Bohm, and Rossi, who was too frail to make the trip from Boston (Fig. 5).
Fig. 5
Roman Jackiw (left) and Nicola Khuri (right). Credit: Courtesy of Roman Jackiw and Nicola Khuri, respectively

Khuri’s mid-October letter is interesting because in it he already gives a partial list of speakers—though it is not clear whether they merely had been asked to speak, or had accepted to speak. The official stationary was not yet available and the letter was to bear the following letterhead:
Shelter Island II
QUANTUM FIELD THEORY AND THE FUNDAMENTAL PROBLEMS OF PHYSICS
Ram’s Head Inn
Shelter Island, N.Y.
June 1–3, 1983

It also listed the organizing committee: S. L Adler, R. W. Jackiw, N. N. Khuri, A. Salam, S. Weinberg, and E. Witten. The letter itself stated:
The Shelter Island Conference which you attended in June 1947 was a watershed in the history of physics and quantum field theory.
We are pleased to invite you to Shelter Island II, to be held June 1–3, 1983. This conference will attempt a critical assessment of the current status of quantum field theory, explore its relation to some of the fundamental problems of physics and cosmology, and identify directions for future developments.
The conference will be held in the same room in Ram’s Head Inn that was used in 1947. This limits us to 85 participants.
The program is still in a state of flux and will be sent to you early in 1983. To date, the list of speakers includes: R. P. Feynman, M. Gell-Mann, R. Jackiw, T. D. Lee, J. Schwinger, S. Weinberg, and E. Witten. We are hopeful that L. Faddeev and A. M. Polyakov will be on the program. In addition Professor Bethe has agreed to organize a panel on Shelter Island I and you will be hearing from him about those plans.
With a special grant from the Andrew Mellon Foundation we are pleased to state that the travel and conference expenses of the Shelter Island I participants who are now retired will be reimbursed.
Please complete the enclosed questionnaire and return it as soon as possible, preferably before December 31, 1982.

Khuri had asked the members of the organizing committee to send him a separate list of “young people” and of older people they thought should be invited. Jackiw sent him a long list containing both. Witten sent him “a list of ‘young’ people” he “might consider inviting,” and added “I have not listed ‘elders’ like Howard Georgi, Dan Freedman, etc., assuming you wanted a list of people who are just a few years out of graduate school.”159

Khuri subsequently demanded very little of the members of the committee. Except for Jackiw, who played an important role in deciding who should be invited and in helping organize the program of the conference, all the demands and responsibilities for making the conference possible were shouldered by Khuri and his very able administrative secretary, Judy Cuozzo. These included obtaining funds to cover the expenditures of the conference, finding hotels to accommodate and feed all the participants, attending to the special needs of some of the participants—such as paying for the flight of the graduate student who would help Hawking, or making sure that Tom Kibble’s young son could sleep in his parents’ room—and making sure that there were adequate toilet facilities at the conference.

Section2.Heading: Attendees
Section2.Para: Several things stand out in looking over the lists of people to be invited that were sent to Khuri by members of the organizing committee.160 Jackiw, in particular, and also Witten, included a large number of foreign participants on their lists, and Khuri made great efforts to have a Chinese and Soviet presence at the conference.161

Other striking facts about the conference were the following:
(1)
In contrast to Shelter Island I, six women theorists were invited to take part in Shelter Island II and attended; five “elders”: Helen Quinn, Nina Byers, Louise Dolan, Mary Gaillard, and So-Yong Pi, and a “young person”: Ling-Lie Chau;
(2)
In sharp contrast to Shelter Island I, there were no experimentalists giving lectures and except for Rodney Cool, who was a colleague of Khuri at Rockefeller University, and Leon Lederman, there were no other experimentalists in attendance;162
(3)
The adjective “fundamental” that was to characterize the conference can be used with two different meanings. On the one hand, it can be understood as implying the search of new properties of physical systems in a given field and their explanation; and on the other, it can imply the search for basic, possibly “ultimate” laws that explain and govern the properties of all matter and energy. Clearly, Khuri and the organizing committee meant “fundamental” in the latter narrower meaning: no condensed matter theorists attended.163

Section2.Heading: The Program
Section2.Para: Since the conference was to commemorate Shelter Island I, part of the opening session was to be devoted to recollections and assessments of Shelter Island I by its participants. In late October 1982, Khuri asked Bethe to organize a two-hour session at the conference to be devoted “to some of the most important topics of Shelter Island I, and discussions where they led to.” On December 8, Bethe wrote to Feynman, Schwinger, Pais, Weisskopf, Lamb, and Kinoshita, the people he wanted to talk at the session. His suggestions for the topics to be addressed, and by whom, were: Bethe and Weisskopf, Kramers’s idea of renormalization; Lamb, the Lamb experiment of 1947 and its further developments; Bethe, the first crude estimate of the Lamb shift; Schwinger and Feynman, the development of covariant QED; Kinoshita, modern experiments and calculations of the magnetic moment of the electron and muon; Marshak, the paradox of the experiment of Piccioni et al., as seen in 1947, and its resolution by the discovery of the pi meson.

In his letter, Bethe noted that he had not asked Pais and Serber to talk, but should they want to do so, they should write to him. Marshak promptly answered him in mid-December 1982 indicating that he was “certainly…in agreement with the program” but suggested the panel to discuss Kramer’s idea of renormalization be composed of Bethe, Pais, and himself, and that Rabi talk about his experiment with Nafe and Nelson on the hyperfine structure of hydrogen and Serber about Oppenheimer.

Feynman only answered in early March 1983, prompted by a further query from Bethe, and asked to be excused from talking, just as had Pais and Serber. He noted that:
The program you outlined seemed very good—if you really want to do it all; because every body knows what things led to. I hope Schweiger [sic] will talk and not me, because I would feel very foolish talking on a subject as old and well known as covariant QED. Is there a way you could leave me in the nirvana now containing Pais and Serber? Thanks.164

On March 9, Pais informed Bethe that his failure to reply to his letter “re reporting at Shelter Island had a reason.” “When I got your letter, I was not at all sure that I would go to that meeting. I am still not sure. So for now: if I come I’ll be glad to help.”

Not having heard from Schwinger, Bethe wrote to him on March 16, 1983, stating that Khuri had informed him that he, Schwinger, would give a talk in the opening session of the Shelter Island II conference, and he therefore assumed that he would not want to give a talk in the reminiscences session. Bethe asked him to confirm that this was indeed the case and hoped that in his talk Schwinger would refer to Shelter Island I and also talk about recent calculations of the Lamb shift.
Schwinger’s reply merits quoting in full:

BlockQuote.Para: Please accept my deepest apologies for not responding to your letters concerning Shelter Island II. From the beginning I have been ambivalent about this meeting. As you may know, I have spent some time in the last few years writing down my remembrances of things past. (To my knowledge, these are still not published.) I cannot imagine changing anything in this documented account, and to be forced into conflict with other people’s attitudes and memories would be painful. Then, as the recently released program makes clear, the supposed historical orientation of the meeting is really only a gimmick, the conference is actually devoted to today’s activities. And, for whatever intellectual or psychological reasons, I do not have much empathy with the current direction; I would not ordinarily go to a meeting of this kind.
Accordingly, I have consulted myself, and decided not to come, although, I regret missing the chance to see you and Rose again.

Section2.Para: Pais also did not attend the conference, probably because Gell-Mann had been asked to give the opening lecture and Gell-Mann and Pais had not been on speaking terms for a long time. Similarly, C. N. Yang did not attend since T. D. Lee had been asked to give a lecture, and he and Lee were likewise not on speaking terms.

The Shelter Island I session had originally been scheduled for the morning session of the opening day, but on April 6, 1983, Bethe wrote Khuri:
It turns out that I shall have to give a lecture at Brookhaven National Laboratory in the evening of May 31. I would therefore be a great convenience to me if it were possible to postpone the session on Reminiscences of Shelter Island I. I realize this would severely interrupt the flow of thought, but I am afraid I will not be in very good condition in the morning of June 1. Could you postpone my session to the morning of June 2, or some other convenient time?
The session was rescheduled for the afternoon.

There is no correspondence in Khuri’s papers on the conference dealing with how the final program was arrived at, except for his mid-October letter to the participants of Shelter Island I and the fact that he had asked Jackiw to write to some of the people he knew well to invite them to talk at the conference.165 The final program was sent to the attendees in late May 1983 (figure 7).

Section1.Heading: The Metaphysics of Shelter Island I and Thereafter
Section1.Para:
It was John Archibald Wheeler (see figure 8), who, at a joint meeting of the National Academy of Sciences and the American Philosophical Society in the fall of 1945, noted that the experimental data in “elementary particle physics” that had been obtained during the 1930s made it possible to identify four “fundamental” interactions: the “strong” forces responsible for nuclear interactions, the electromagnetic forces between electrically charged particles, the “weak” forces responsible for beta decay, and the gravitational forces. It was evident that the gravitational forces could be neglected when considering elementary particle processes, given the weakness of the force and the distances being probed by experiments. When the first Rochester Conference was held in 1950, most physicists held the view that electrons, photons, protons, neutrons, π-mesons, µ-mesons, and neutrinos were “elementary particles”; that the four interactions were independent realms and that quantum electrodynamics, pseudoscalar meson theory, and Fermi’s beta decay theory were “fundamental” theories of the electromagnetic, nuclear and weak interactions. But what became clear very quickly was that the elucidation of the dynamics of the subnuclear world would require their simultaneous consideration.

Section1.Para: By the late 1950s, with the discovery of the plethora of new “strange” “elementary particles” and the failure of meson theories to account for the nuclear forces, it was realized that the traditional view that correlated a quantum field with each “elementary particle” was not tenable when trying to understand the hadronic world. The formulation of the theory of strong interactions proved to be more involved, and required the elucidation of the dependence of the cross section of deep inelastic electron-proton scattering on energy. These 1968 experiments at SLAC introduced the notion of scaling by James Bjorken, and of essentially freely moving sub-nuclear constituents of hadrons by both Bjorken and by Feynman, who called them partons. Their connection with the quarks that had been introduced by Gell-Mann and Zweig as fictitious entities to elucidate the SU(3) symmetries of the hadron spectrum, and the incorporation of the color properties attributed to them by Greenberg, eventually led to the present day theory of the strong interactions, quantum chromodynamics, a non-abelian gauge theory. Its crucial property of being asymptotically free, as proven by David Politzer192 and by David Gross and Frank Wilczek,193 explained the weakness of the interactions between quarks at short distances and thus the success of the parton model in explaining scaling. Furthermore, the analysis of renormalizable relativistic quantum field theories by the renormalization group approach that Curtis Callan and Gross194 as well as Kenneth Wilson195 had developed from 1968 to 1973 led to the deeply significant conclusion that only gauge theories of the Yang-Mills type could have the property of being asymptotically free.196

When Shelter Island II took place, key components of the standard model had been corroborated by experiments accurate to 5%.197 As then formulated, the model amalgamated the Glashow-Weinberg-Salam SU(2)×U(1) electroweak theory with QCD based on the SU(3) color group as the gauge group.

The success of electroweak theory raised the question whether it is possible to “grand unify” the standard model, i.e. whether it is possible to formulate a gauge field theory in which the strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions would be described a single simple gauge group with a single coupling constant, with the quarks and leptons and their antiparticles combined in the same multiplet. In 1974, Howard Georgi and Sheldon Glashow formulated an SU(5) model that was the first full unification of SU(3)×SU(2)×U(1) into a simple group with a single coupling constant. It yielded electric charge quantification, and thus explained why the electron and the proton have an electric charge of equal magnitude. It also predicted that the proton would decay, but would possess an extremely long lifetime, of the order of 1030 years.198 Though looked for, proton decay has not yet been observed, indicating that it has a lifetime greater than 1032 years.199 Note that proton decay implies that baryon number is not conserved in this grand unified theory (GUT).

In the standard model, the gauge coupling constants of the SU(3), SU(2), and U(1) groups are independent quantities. Because of the effects of quantum fluctuations and their renormalization, these coupling constants must be understood as running parameters whose value change with the distance scale being explored, or equivalently with the energy scale being explored. The running of the gauge couplings is described by renormalization group equations. In 1974, Georgi, Helen Quinn, and Weinberg200 showed that the three gauge couplings would meet approximately at some high energy unification scale M
X ∼ 3×1016 GeV, thereby giving support to the notion of the existence of a GUT, in which the three interactions are unified and the GUT symmetry is broken at some scale of the order M
X ∼ 3×1016 GeV by a Higgs mechanism, but above which breaking would not operate.

Section1.Heading: GUTs and Cosmology
Section1.Para: Grand unified theories offered insights into what might lie beyond the standard model. Still, the most dramatic predictions of GUTs occur at the energy scale of 1015 GeV or so. But the only situation in which such high energies existed was in the very early universe, in the immediate aftermath of the big bang. The corroboration of the big bang cosmological hypothesis occurred in 1965.201

At the end of the 1920s, Edwin Hubble had established that the universe was expanding, with each galaxy receding from every other galaxy with a velocity proportional to the distance between them. Hubble’s law is usually written with our galaxy as singled out. It then states that v = Hl, where v is the recession velocity of the observed galaxy l its distance from us, and H is Hubble’s constant, a “constant” that varies as the universe evolves. This picture of a homogeneous expansion of the universe when extrapolated backward in time implies that at some instant in the past all the galaxies coalesced and the density of the universe and its temperature were infinite. Although there had been earlier speculations, by Friedmann and Lemaitre, about the evolution of the universe from a big bang, it was George Gamow and his students, Ralph Alpher and Robert Herman, who, in the late 1940s, made use of the extant knowledge of nuclear physics, to make the study of the early universe an integral part of cosmology. Gamow pointed out that the very early, very hot universe would have been permeated by black body radiation and that as the universe evolved from its hot initial state and expanded, this black body radiation would have cooled, and the universe at present would be bathed by the cooled black body radiation whose temperature he estimated to be around 7 K. Gamow, Alpher, and Herman’s prediction was confirmed in 1964 when Arno A. Penzias and Robert W. Wilson discovered an isotropic uniform background of microwave radiation with an effective temperature of about 3 K.202 It quickly became accepted that the uniform microwave background radiation (MBR) that Penzias and Wilson had discovered was the primordial fireball.203

The second set of phenomena Gamow investigated to support the big bang theory was concerned with nucleosynthesis in the very early universe before galaxies and stars had formed. Based on the assumption that neutrons were the primordial elements, such calculations were first undertaken by Alpher, Gamow, and Herman in the late 1940s.204 The modern theory of cosmological nucleosynthesis was formulated in 1966 by P. J. E. Peebles, who at the time was a student in Dicke’s group studying cosmology. Dicke, in the early 1960s, had started a program of experimental gravitational research at Princeton and in 1966 had set up an experiment to detect the cosmic background radiation that would be the remnant of conditions of the early universe in the oscillating model of cosmology he believed in, in which the universe expanded and contracted.

Peebles assumed the validity of the big bang theory. Given the ambient temperature during the first few minutes after the big bang, there were virtually no nuclei present since nuclei would be not be able to remain bound in that environment. The universe then consisted of a hot gas of photons and neutrinos, with a very much smaller density of protons, neutrons, and electrons. As the universe cooled, the protons and neutrons combined to form nuclei. Extending earlier calculations by Alpher, Follin, and Herman, Peebles calculated the expected abundances of the light chemical elements—deuterons, He3, He4, and Li7. He found that most of the matter in the universe would remain in the form of hydrogen, with about 25% by mass being converted into He4 which was 108 times more abundant than lithium 7. These numbers depended on the present abundance of protons and neutrons in the universe (though that was not known with great accuracy) but were in general agreement with the observed cosmic abundance of these elements.

Going back in time in the history of the universe correlates temporal changes with temperature changes. One uses the temperature changes to conjecture a historical process for the evolution of the universe in a big bang scenario. Thus, if one goes back sufficiently in time one arrives at an era when the temperature and density were so high so that radiation and matter were in thermal equilibrium. But as the universe expanded and the temperature dropped the radiation went out of equilibrium with matter. However, a detailed analysis indicates that the black body spectrum when matter and radiation were in equilibrium was preserved as the photons went out of equilibrium with matter. The story of the evolution of the universe from the time it was a very hot plasma of electrons, positrons, and neutrinos, and a very small density of neutrons, protons, deuterons, and helium atoms can be told with some confidence.205

After QCD was formulated, the question arose whether the standard model could be incorporated in that framework, with quarks, gluons, and leptons being the “elementary” constituents of the primordial soup. Also of great importance were the details of how the symmetry breaking mechanism would explain why the electroweak interactions are different from the strong interactions at energies below the GUT energy. Kirzhnits and Linde in 1972 had qualitatively investigated whether a global broken symmetry would be restored if the temperature were sufficiently high.206 In 1974, Weinberg took up the problem and investigated the case of local broken symmetries in relativistic quantum field theories—in particular in gauge theories—and showed how to calculate the critical temperature at which a phase transition occurs for general renormalizable fields using a Feynman diagrammatic approach. At Weinberg’s suggestion, Jackiw also took up the problem of spontaneous symmetry breaking at finite temperature and showed how to calculate the critical temperature more generally using functional methods.207 In Weinberg, and in Dolan and Jackiw, the spontaneous symmetry breaking is accomplished by a Higgs-like scalar field that acquires a non-zero vacuum expectation value. The phase transition occurs because thermal fluctuations at high temperatures destroy the non-zero expectation value of the Higgs field.

Several authors had speculated that before this Robertson-Walker era there was an earlier period of inflation, during which R(t) grew exponentially. Thus, for example, in December 1979 Alexei Starobinsky published a theory of inflation in a well-known Soviet journal that was translated into English.211 He indicated that a characteristic spectrum of primordial gravitational waves would be produced from any inflationary universe, regardless of the model. But his contribution did not receive the attention it merited, perhaps because it did not deal with particle physics. Inflation attracted little attention until Alan Guth “incited interest…by noting what it was good for.”212

In the late 1970s, Guth was working with Henry Tye on seeing what happens to SU(5) magnetic monopoles in the early universe. They made use of Coleman’s model for the potential of the Higgs-like scalar fields that spontaneously broke the SU(5) symmetry to SU(3)×SU(2)×U(1). They also made use of Coleman’s calculations for the decay rate of the false vacuum, i.e. when Higgs-like scalar fields get caught in a local minimum of the potential, which is a state with unbroken SU(5) symmetry. This false vacuum has a huge negative pressure. Guth realized that this peculiar feature of the false vacuum would have a dramatic effect on the evolution of the universe. It would produce a constant rate of expansion, i.e. an R(t) that grows exponentially. Barrier penetration eventually stops the inflation, with the scalar fields rolling down the potential toward the global minimum, the broken symmetry state, which corresponds to the present universe. The vacuum energy of this broken symmetry state must be small otherwise it would be the source of a large cosmological constant, implying that the vacuum energy of the false vacuum must have been high.

Guth also noted that besides the monopole problem that depended on the SU(5) GUT, inflation could solve three problems in cosmology, and give answers that depended only weakly on any GUT, answers that non-inflationary models could not provide. These three problems were:
(1)
How did the universe become so homogeneous on large scales?
(2)
Why is the mass density of the early universe so extraordinarily close to the critical density?
(3)
Can one find a physical origin for the primordial density perturbations that led to the evolution of galaxies and clusters of galaxies?

Guth’s original formulation of inflation assumed that it would end with the formation of bubbles of broken symmetry surrounded by the metastable unbroken symmetry vacuum state. But these bubbles would have expanded and collided and would have left the universe in a much more inhomogeneous state than observed. This difficulty was removed by Albrecht and Steinhardt, by Linde, and by Hawking and Moss, who indicated that the symmetry could be broken slowly in a homogeneous manner. Moreover, they predicted that the present density of the universe would be very close to the critical density. They also made predictions regarding the deviations from exact homogeneity and isotropy that should be observable in the cosmic background radiation. Nevertheless, their model likewise succumbed to criticisms: the resulting inhomogeneities were found to be much too great to lead to galaxies and instead led to superdense objects or black holes.213 Guth, Linde, and Hawking made extensive presentations at Shelter Island II regarding the very early universe. Guth reviewed the basic assumptions and limitations of the basic inflationary model; Linde presented a new inflationary scenario involving supergravity and chaotic initial conditions in the very early universe; and Hawking his speculations why the cosmological constant is probably zero.214

It is one of the startling facts about the Shelter Island II conference that inflation—a theory that makes conjectures about what happened from 10−36 to 10−33 seconds after the big bang—should receive that much attention. That inflation is a falsifiable theory—in particular, its predictions of some of the properties of the fluctuations in the cosmic microwave background—is surely a factor for its respectful reception. In 2008, Weinberg would write: “So far the details of inflation are unknown, and the whole idea of inflation remains a speculation, though one that is increasingly plausible.”215

Although inflation assumed center stage at Shelter Island II, recall that I asserted earlier that it was not a watershed conference in terms of new ideas but rather highlighted the important changes that were taking place. There is little doubt that it was the 1982 Nuffield workshop216 that had been a watershed in taking inflation seriously217 and cementing the amalgamation of particle physics and cosmology. That workshop had been organized by Stephen Hawking and Gary Gibbons and its focus was on “The Very Early Universe,” more precisely on the history of the universe’s initial cooling and expansion in a spatially uniform and isotropic manner during the first second after the big bang. There were twenty-five participants in the three-week-long workshop, all of them either particle physicists or cosmologists, five from the Soviet Union, the remaining from the US and Europe.218

The aim of that workshop was to attempt accounting for the conditions of the cosmological standard model at one second after the big bang. The agreement between the observations of the abundances of the light elements and the predictions of the big bang model gave confidence that the model was valid up to that time. In particular, the challenge was to explain:
(1)
Why was the universe spatially uniform and isotropic over length scales much bigger than 1010 cm, the horizon size at one second?
(2)
Why, despite this uniformity, were there small irregularities which later developed into stars and galaxies?
(3)
Why was the universe spatially flat to within one part in 1016, i.e. why was the universe expanding at almost exactly the critical rate to avoid recollapse?
(4)
Why was the ratio of photons to baryons about 10−9?
(5)
Did the universe contain significant numbers of exotic objects such as magnetic monopoles, strings, small black holes, axions, photoni, gravitini, and other -ini?
(6)
Why is the cosmological constant so small that it has not been measurable, whereas one might expect quantum effects to make it 10120 times larger?219

The basic assumption in all the attempts to answer the above questions was that the average energies of particles increases as one goes back in time in the first few seconds after the big bang. When these energies were greater than the Planck energy, 1019 GeV, some—presently unknown—quantum gravity theory is an essential component of the appropriate description of the dynamics of that era of the evolution of the universe. At energies lower than 1019 GeV, presumably quantum gravitational effect were negligible and the dynamics of the quantum fields present evolved in a space-time adequately described by general relativity. Quantum fields in curved space-time are supposed to be an adequate approximation to quantum gravity. They actually exhibit new features that have important physical consequences, the most important being black hole evaporation and quantum fluctuations in the early universe. An important feature of quantum fields in curved space is that the vacuum state can evolve into an excited state. Not only can particles be produced by a time-dependent space-time background, but particle production can also occur in a locally static space-time like that of a Schwartzschild black hole.

Furthermore, in the energy region between 1019 GeV and 1015 GeV, some GUT is assumed to be the appropriate description of the dynamics of the quantum fields, possibly a GUT that incorporates supersymmetry, a symmetry that relates particles of integral spin with particles of half-integral spin. Supersymmetric theories have certain attractive technical features because cancellation between bosonic and fermionic closed loop reduces drastically the divergences encountered in perturbative calculations. Supergravity was at the center of discussions at the Nuffield workshop.

But before turning to some remarks about supersymmetry, let me make an observation about the participants of the 1982 Nuffield workshop. There is a remarkable picture of the participants of the 1982 Nuffield workshop.220 Sciama evidently was not present when the picture was taken. Except for the 76-year-old Mosey Markov, the respected senior Soviet cosmologist, everyone in the picture was born after the advent of quantum mechanics, in fact primarily in the 1940s or thereafter. The oldest, Sciama, was born in 1926. He participated in the workshop as the most distinguished British cosmologist and the mentor and teacher of a remarkable group of astrophysicists, among others: George Ellis (PhD 1964), Stephen Hawking (1966), Brandon Carter (1967), Martin Rees (1967), Gary Gibbons (1973), James Binney (1975), John D. Barrow (1977), David Deutsch (1979), Adrian Melott (1981), Philip Candelas.221

Thus, a new generation established inflationary cosmology, a post–World War II generation for whom quantum field theory was the language for describing subnuclear phenomena, and a generation that experienced the upheaval of the 1960s and 1970s.

The single-particle states of such a supersymmetric theory fall into irreducible representations of the supersymmetry algebra, called supermultiplets, the members of which all having the same mass. Each supermultiplet contains both fermion and boson states, which are commonly known as superpartners of each other, each supermultiplet containing an equal number of fermion and boson degrees of freedom. Soon after the formulation of supersymmetric theories, it was recognized that they had remarkable renormalization properties rendering finite some of the Feynman loop diagrams. How this happens, in which supersymmetrized theories, and why this happens was reviewed by West225 in his presentation at Shelter Island II.226

The fact that in the supersymmetric version of SU(5) the three couplings meet at a point gave support not only to supersymmetry, but to the notion that a more unified foundational theory might exist. The problem of how to unify the electroweak and the strong forces, and how to incorporate gravity into such a unified theory was considered one of the most fundamental, unsolved, problems.

Yet it was recognized that the usual approach to “quantizing” field systems, whether by Feynman’s path integral or by more conventional approaches, could not overcome the difficulties encountered when attempting to formulate a quantum theory of gravity. By the early 1980s, it had became apparent, through the work of John Schwarz and others, that string theory offered a framework for overcoming the difficulties encountered in quantizing gravity.227 The theory arose in the late 1960s as an alternative to quantum field theory in which the fundamental entities are considered oscillations of one-dimensional strings rather than zero dimensional points, a particle being just a string in a particular state of vibration. In string theory, interactions are spread out over the strings rather than concentrated at a single point, thereby preventing infinities. The existence of a spin-two graviton in the theory came to be seen as a necessary feature of string theory, and string theorists came to characterize gravity as an essential component of and a “prediction” of string theory. Supersymmetry likewise became considered to be another general prediction of string theory.

Witten has made the point that if the real and complex numbers are regarded as real vector spaces, then the dimension of the real vector space is one, that of the complex vector space is two. The orbit of a point particle in space-time is a real one-dimensional manifold, while that of a string in space-time is two-dimensional and should be regarded as a complex Riemann surface. Hence, for Witten, “physics without strings is roughly analogous to mathematics without complex numbers.”228

One can think of the motion of a string through space as sweeping out a two-dimensional surface so that string theory is the theory of these two-dimensional surfaces. The dynamical problems of strings using the Feynman integral-over-paths involves summing over all possible two-dimensional surfaces. Mathematicians had classified all possible two-dimensional surfaces according to their topology. Hence, physicists made use of these results. Conversely, supersymmetry provided a powerful new mathematical tool in the exploration of topological properties.

Supersymmetry was at the center of many of the presentations at Shelter Island II. In addition to P. C. West’s lecture on “Supersymmetry and Finiteness” of quantum field theories, Bruno Zumino lectured on the application of supersymmetric models to the proof of the Atiyah-Singer index theorem.229

In the attempts to unify gravitation and gauge theories, Kaluza-Klein theories and their supersymmetric extensions attracted a great deal of attention in the late 1970s. At Shelter Island II, M. J. Duff lectured on the consequence of the making Kaluza-Klein versions of gravitational theory supersymmetric, as did Witten in his lecture on “Fermion Quantum Numbers in Kaluza-Klein Theory.”230

String theory was very much at the center of interest of many of the younger participants of Shelter Island II. String theory’s point of departure had been in S-matrix theory, but it has become clear that quantum field theories and string theories are deeply intertwined and related by dualities. John Schwarz, one of the developers of and an important contributor to the field, has come to see string theory “as the logical completion of quantum field theory.”231

Section1.Heading: Physics and Mathematics
Section1.Para: Philip J. Davis and Reuben Hersh, in their perceptive book on The Mathematical Experience, defined mathematics as “the study of mental objects with reproducible properties.”233 Their pointing to reproducibility and to the mental aspect of the enterprise captures something essential about mathematics. Indeed, a great deal of mathematics had its origin in physics, in the study of permanent objects and the reproducibility/periodicity of their motions. David Mumford has gone further than Davis and Hirsh. In an essay on “The Dawning of The Age of Stochasticity,” he argued that all of mathematics arose and arises “by abstracting some aspect of our experiences, and that alongside the mathematics which arises from objects and their motions in the material world, formal logic arose, in the work of Aristotle, from observing thought itself.”234

That mathematicians at times construct mathematical entities and structures seemingly developed to satisfy strictly internal needs of the discipline, which later on find useful and important applications in physics is well known. Riemannian geometry, its Levi-Civita tensor calculus formulation, and its appropriation by Einstein as the framework and the mathematical language of general relativity is an oft-cited example of this phenomenon. Yet Riemannian geometry traces its root to Gauss’s efforts to abstract some of his efforts concerning geodesy.235

In an essay in the volume issued in 2000 by the International Mathematical Union addressing Frontiers and Perspectives of mathematics in the new century, Witten tried to foresee some of the possible influence of physics on mathematics by describing past trends. He pointed to general relativity giving a big boost to the growth of Riemannian geometry during the twentieth century. Differentiating between the quantum theory of particles and the “deeper part of quantum theory, the quantum theory of fields,” Witten attributed much of the development of functional analysis, spectral theory and related areas during the twentieth century to the former, but believed that “in some sense most of the [quantum theory of fields]’s influence on mathematics belongs to the twenty-first century.” He considered the standard model with its non-abelian gauge theories and asymptotic freedom as having set the stage “for a new kind of interaction between quantum field theory and geometry.” Subsequently, supersymmetry and string theory led physicists to gradually ask new kind of questions that involved geometrical concepts and techniques not previously used in physics. In time it was realized that things could be turned around, and that quantum field theory methods could be used to draw inferences about geometry. And so it is that, although quantum field theory is a rather old subject, its mathematical influence is in many respects rather recent, and still lies mainly in the future.236

To amplify Witten’s remarks: in the 1960s and 1970s, mathematicians and physicists witnessed a confluence of concepts and ideas. On one side were the abelian and non-abelian gauge theories describing the electroweak and strong interactions; on the other was an internally motivated extension of Riemannian geometry involving mathematical structures known as fiber bundles. When studying the topology and differential geometry of surfaces in an arbitrary number of dimensions, mathematicians found it useful to introduce auxiliary spaces, such as the space consisting of the tangent planes to the surface being studied or the space of lines normal to that surface. Such spaces are called fiber bundles, the fibers being the auxiliary spaces and the bundle the totality of fibers that are fitted together. The classification of bundles and their invariants was studied in the 1930s and 1940s by Hassler Whitney, Norman Steenrod, Lev Pontrjagin, Shiing-Shen Chern, and others. They obtained integral formulas for the invariants of bundles that generalize the Gauss-Bonnet formula. The latter states that the integral of the Gaussian curvature over an entire surface is a topological invariant—that is, the value of the integral is not changed by local deformation of the surface—and is a multiple of 2π.

The mathematician Isadore Singer, who with Michael Atiyah had formulated the famous Atiyah-Singer index theorem, made a presentation at Shelter Island II on the content of that theorem. A year earlier he had written an article in Physics Today which gave a very informative and accessible overview of the connection between gauge theories, differential geometry, and topology.237 Singer’s lecture was not included in the proceedings. However, Feynman took some notes of the lectures.238

Feynman’s notes indicate that Singer was presenting the main result of the Atiyah-Singer index theorem in a way that makes connection to the language of supersymmetry. He was summarizing the “heat kernel proof of the index theorem” in the language of super-symmetry. The connection between supersymmetry and the Atiyah-Singer index theory was “in the air” at Shelter Island II. The connection was made explicit in a paper entitled “Supersymmetric Derivation of the Atiyah-Singer Index Theorem and the Chiral Anomaly” by Friedan and Windey (1984). The acknowledgment of that paper begins with the statement: “We would like to thank I. M. Singer whose report of a discussion with E. Witten initiated this work.”239

Although he is definitely a physicist (as his list of publications clearly shows) his command of mathematics is rivalled by few mathematicians, and his ability to interpret physical ideas in mathematical form is quite unique.
