But we do not have a similar narrative for Roman Jackiw, who played a central role in transferring abstract mathematical methods into quantum field theory, except for some remarks in some of his essays in his Collected Works. 254 Nor do we have a history—in the time period under consideration—of the remarkable physics community located in the greater Boston area, with its multitude of universities (Harvard, MIT, Boston University, Brandeis, Tufts, etc.) with Coleman, Ken Johnson, Glashow, Low, Schwinger, and Weinberg setting the intellectual agendas, attracting outstanding graduate students and members of Harvard’s Society of Fellows (such as Gross, Jackiw, Georgi, Politzer, and others).255 Nor is there a history of the Berkeley region, and the interaction there of physicists (such as Mandelstam, Zumino) with mathematicians (Singer); similarly for the ETH in Zurich;256 nor of the seminal interactions of physicists with mathematicians in Moscow (in Gelfand’s, Arnol’d’s, Manin’s and Sinai’s seminars) or in Leningrad.257

In concluding this section, I want to reemphasize the novel symbiotic nature of the connection that evolved between physics and mathematics, a bond that was already manifest at Shelter Island II. What is new about this interaction, and why I have labeled it “novel” is that it is concerned with ideas at the forefront of theoretical physics and of mathematics and that it involves the leading geometers and the leading field theorists and string theorists. Manin, in his essay on “Mathematics as Profession and Vocation,” has given the most succinct characterization of this new symbiosis. He noted that: “Mathematics has no fixed rules of semantic interpretation in the physical world: the same wave equation can describe ocean waves, sound, light, and ‘waves of probability’ in quantum mechanics. In this sense, mathematics is a great source of metaphors. The act of interpretation of a mathematical construction in, say theoretical physics, must be separated from the construction itself.” Manin went on to observe:
a less traditional relationship has crystallized [between mathematics and physics] since the 70s. Simultaneously with the success of the “standard model” which satisfactorily described the observable spectrum of elementary particles and interactions, physicists started developing rather romantic models that might be relevant at the very high energy of the Big Bang. The study of these models required and stimulated the development of sophisticated and sometimes amazingly new mathematics, mostly connected with the quantum theory of fields and strings. This process is in full swing now.
In my opinion, one can now speak about the emerging program of “quantization of classical mathematics” which has a wider scope than just cooperation with the physicists in a common endeavor to understand the theory of quantum strings.258

Section1.Heading: Epilogue
Section1.Para:
In the facetious opening paragraph of his essay “Polymathematics: Is Mathematics a Single or Science or a Set of Arts,” the great Russian mathematician Vladimir Arnol’d commented:
All mathematics is divided in three parts: cryptography (paid for by CIA, KBG, and the like), hydrodynamics (supported by manufacturers of atomic submarines) and celestial mechanics (financed by military and other institutions dealing with missiles, such as NASA).
Cryptography has generated number theory, algebraic geometry over finite fields, algebra,259 combinatorics and computers.
Hydrodynamics procreated complex analysis, partial differential equations, Lie groups and algebra theory, cohomology theory and scientific computing.
Celestial mechanics is the origin of dynamical systems, linear algebra, topology, variational calculus and symplectic geometry.
The existence of mysterious relations between all these different domains is the most striking and delightful feature of mathematics (having no rational explanation).260

The strong coupling between pure mathematics and the more nefarious aspects of state power are even more pronounced in the case of physics. One can argue that Shelter Island I assembled a group of leading young American physicists who had been endowed with self-confidence by the war time work they had done, work that had produced the means to give the United States a victorious conclusion to World War II. These young physicists—in part to purify themselves—went on to produce a usable quantum electrodynamics and laid the foundations for making possible the formulation of the standard model later on.

Shelter Island II brought together leading young physicists who had been endowed with self-confidence by the work they, and other members of their generation, had done to create outstanding pure physics: “the standard model.” That is why inflation could be taken so seriously at the conference and why, despite the fact that no detailed experimental predictions could be made from string theory, these young physicists nonetheless would invest huge efforts into advancing the theory during the next two decades until the LHC went into operation.

But this separation between pure and whatever one wants to call it—applied, engineering—physics is tenuous. In fact, because Shelter Island II was in part convened to celebrate the physicists who had made Shelter Island I so memorable made the connection between physics and power explicit at the most important social function of the conference: its banquet.

David E. DeCosse, a reporter for the East Hampton Star attended the banquet that was held on June 2. He opened his long description of “A Conclave of Physics” in the June 8 issue of the paper with the statement: “At a time when the world is forcefully reacting to the threat of nuclear power,261 and in a week of civil protest at the Shoreham nuclear plant, some of the scientists who had harnessed the power of the atom and some who are now approaching an understanding of the creation of the universe gathered last week in placid surroundings on Shelter Island for a conference called Shelter Island II: Quantum Field Theory and the Fundamental Problems of Physics.”

DeCosse reported that at the banquet Professor Steven Weinberg had toasted his Shelter Island I predecessors for having “both reasserted science and playing a heroic and terribly important part in winning the War.” And he noted that at other times during the evening the “earlier period was remembered as a courageous and productive time.”

After the banquet, DeCosse interviewed both Stephen Hawking and Victor Weisskopf. A somewhat optimistic Hawking told him that the conference was concerned with what had been called the grand unification theory “that describes the behavior of all the forces of nature” as well as “the yet not fully-understood ‘big bang’, the beginning of the universe, [and that it] had a ‘50-50’ chance of being uncovered by the end of the century.” Hawking thought that this grand unified theory, when found, “it will influence the way people think about themselves and the world they live in. It will be the same way that Einstein’s theory of relativity influenced the way people thought even though they did not understand it.”

But it was nuclear weapons, and the making of nuclear weapons by physicists, that dominated the interview. DeCosse quoted Weisskopf, a veteran of both Los Alamos and of Shelter Island I, as saying: “We had to do it [building the bomb]. This country was in a war, and one has to serve one’s country.” He gave as the motivation for the concentrated effort to build the bomb the fear of the Nazis beating the Americans in producing the bomb because they had discovered fission and presumably had started working on a bomb soon thereafter.

Commenting on DeCosse’s observation that whereas Shelter Island I had looked back two years to the use of two atomic bombs, Shelter Island II looked back to thirty-six years of proliferation of weapons of far greater destructive power, Hawking remarked that “the difference that we have with the Russians are unimportant compared with the possibility of total annihilation.” Weisskopf was pessimistic: “mankind is doomed” unless “the growing revulsion with the nuclear buildup, exemplified by the freeze movement and the recent Catholic Bishops’ pastoral letter on nuclear arms, spreads throughout the population.”262

The concept of a community of practice is due to Jean Lave and Etienne Wenger who in their book Situated Learning: Legitimate Peripheral Participation (Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press, 1991) offered a new viewpoint of “learning.” Classical learning theory conceived of learning as an individual process whereby a formal body of knowledge is acquired from a teacher or from an expert. Learning was a psychological process whose foci were the brains of individuals. For Lave and Wenger social participation is the essential mechanism for learning. Moreover, for them knowledge is not a stable commodity that can be transmitted. After the publication of Wenger’s books many sociologists, historians, and philosophers of science have adopted the view of considering the sciences as communities of practice committed to research enterprises that are expansive and prospective, and have placed particular emphasis on the community’s pervasive social entanglement. Helpful points of entry to that literature are Joseph Rouse, Engaging Science: How to Understand Its Practices Philosophically (Ithaca NY: Cornell University Press, 1996); How Scientific Practices Matter: Reclaiming Philosophical Naturalism (Chicago: The University of Chicago Press, 2003); Articulating the World: Conceptual Understanding and the Scientific Image (Chicago: The University of Chicago Press, 2015).

A function describing a property of hadrons that can be measured in high-energy scattering experiments is said to scale when its value is not determined by the energy at which the measurement is being carried out, but is determined by dimensionless kinematic quantities such as the ratio of the energy to a momentum transfer. Increasing the energy of the probing particle implies decreasing its wavelength, and thus being able to resolve more precisely the spatial features of what is being probed. Thus the property of “scaling” for a cross-section implies that the resolution scale of the scatterer does not depend on length, and hence that effectively what ever is responsible for the scattering has a point-like substructure. Scaling behavior for the structure functions of deep inelastic scattering of electrons on nucleons was first proposed by James Bjorken in 1968.
